Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n>    - E<n>

Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The answer is: E<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>* Answer:E<n>* Demonstration:The key concept for this problem is to look at the choices that have cable in the product name as well as the equipment that can't survive without cable.<n>* Explanation:Cable is essential equipment for these things: 1) television; 2) radio; 3) desk; 4) cabinet; 5) substation and finally 6) radio shack.<n>* Steps:1)First I looked to see if the product names contain cable or has to do with cable. 2)Then I looked to see if that one product requires cable. If the answer was yes then we put a box next to it. Then, we choose the one that doesn't have a box, thus the answer can't be this product.<n>* Steps2: 1)Then I looked to confirm if cable was present or not. 2)Next, I looked to see what items required cable for operation. If one of them required cable, that was the answer.

Choices:  A: town B: at hotel C: mall D: business sector E: yellow pages<n><n>### Response:		A: (only if given that the restaurant is business oriented and not located in the residential area.)<n><n>### Input (1):You want to buy a new bike. It costs $20 more than the one you are selling. What do you do?<n>Input (2): Write a statement to solve the problem of finding the total cash after you sell your bike.<n><n>Input (3): How you can write a program to find the total cash after selling your bike?<n><n>### Response (1): You can have a statement like this:<n><n>```<n>let totalCash = 20*((45/100)-10)<n>```<n><n>`totalCash` gets the money left as your cash.<n><n>```<n>let newCash = totalCash + cash<n>```<n><n>`newCash` gets the total cash after the sale.<n><n>### Response 2: <n>```<n>let money = newCash - cash<n>```<n>Now you can have: <n>  ```<n>  newCash = 1600<n>  money = 1400<n>  ```<n><n>### Response(3): Write statement in while loop. <n><n>### Input<n><n>### Input(1): You go to the mall to find a dress for your new job. There were 25 different dresses on sale including yours. You were able to buy one at 40% off and the others were $30 each. You only had $52 with you. How many did you buy?<n>Input(2): Write a statement in if...else to decide if the number of dress you are able to buy is less or equal to one.<n>Input(3): How will you be able to decide if the number or dress you are able to by is less or equal to the number of dress you were able to bought.<n><n>### response(1):<n>```<n>if(dressAmount <=5 ) then<n>    var result = dressAmount*0.40<n>    let price = 17*(1 - dressAmount/1)<n>else<n>    var result = 30<n>```<n><n>### Response : <n>`dressAmount` represents the dresses that you were able to buy in total.<n><n>1:  The dress amount that you are

Choices:  A: maine B: boston C: beach town D: coastal cities E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		Where would you find a sea food restaurant on East coast?<n><n>### Input<n>When I was in the US, I went to Beach town for vacation and I ate lots of oyster and clam. It was really delicious. Have you ever visited the east coast of North American?<n><n>### Response<n>Yes, I have. I was in New England part of US, I went to maine first, then went to Boston when I was there, I met some locals and I asked them about the seafood they are eating and they told me they like eating clam, oyster, and shell fish. They usually ate oyster barbeque at the weekend.<n><n><n><n>

"True" : "False";<n>    System.out.println(answer);<n>```<n> <n>### Instruction<n>Write a method that returns the number of vowels in a string.<n><n>### Explanation<n>To count the number of vowel in a string do the following. Create a while loop that will repeat two times, while the loop is running, check the character at the current index of loop as shown below.<n><n>```java<n>    int count_of_vowel = 0;<n>    while (i < text.length()){<n>         if(text.charAt(i) == 'a' || text.charAt(i == 'I' || text.charat(i) == 'o' || text.charaAt(i) =='e' || text.char(i) == 'u')<n>         {   <n>             count_of_vowels = 1;<n>             i++;<n>  <n>         }<n>    }<n>    System.out("there is " + count_of_vowed + " vowel in this string" );<n>```<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a method that determines whether a date is a leap year.<n>```<n>    @overridingMethod<n>    boolean isLeapYear(int year) {<n>        if (year % 2 == 0) {<n>            return false;<n>        }<n>        else {<n>            return true;<n>        }<n>    }<n>```<n><n>## Expected Output<n>    True<n>    <n><n>## Instructions<n>Write your own method, which prompts the user to enter two integers, and then prints “The sum of these two integers is “ + (int) ( (numA + numB) ).<n><n><n>###  Expected outputs<n>When i enter 2 as the two numbers the method returns 4. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Sometimes fighting inflation isn't even what, because it is so negligible? What does it mean?<n><n>### Response:"Do I look fat?" means ask someone (typically one's significant other) whether their clothing makes them look fuller than they are. The question, "Do I look fat in...?" means asking this question and adding the object where the clothing is worn. The question is an extension of the original question and does not mean to actually look fat. <n><n>### Input"The man who shrank me was a magician. He had the ability to shrink people using a spell." - Who shrank you?<n><n>### From the clue(s), answer the following question with a complete and grammatically correct sentence.<n>"What did I shake him?" - Who shook him?<n><n>### InputThe newest generation of cellphones is called a smartphone because?<n><n>### AnswerCellphones that come with all sorts of new features are often called smartphones. The name for these devices comes from the fact that they can be used to solve all sorts of problems for the user. The user should be happy that he or she knows how to use the functions.

I have not figured it out yet.<n>### Input:A: kick the bucket B C: dead D:can die E: dying<n>### Response:**B. mortal.**<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the task request.<n><n>## Solution<n><n>### Instructio:<n>Write a response with the correct answer to the instruction above.<n><n>### Input A: kick the bucket<n><n>### Response A:**mortal.**<n><n>The response is A -> mortal but the answer I got was B. Could someone please tell me how?<n><n>## Detection Code<n><n>### Input B: dead<n><n>### Response B:**dead.**<n><n>The input was choice 2 from choice A and B. The correct answer is still B though. What can I do?<n><n>### Input C: can die<n><n>### Response C:**can die.**<n><n>The correct answer is also C but the output is always the same.<n><n>### Response D:**dyeing.**<n><n>The incorrect answer is D. <n><n>### Instution:<n>Write a response<n><n>## Solution for 4.5 in 18, 140 in 32, 67 in 90, and 180 in 80<n><n>### input 4.5 in<n><n>### output 5.5 in<n><n># How do I get the correct answer here?<n><n>### input:<n>I have not figured it out<n><n>### outputs:<n>I have not figure out yet<n><n># How do i do it?<n><n>### input for 4.5<n><n>### input<n><n>### output<n><n>### input How many blocks did PETE travel in all?

When writing the steps, consider if the steps are in the same order each time or if they can be done in different orders.<n>### Instruments:<n>1.<n>2.<n>3.<n>4.<n><n>### Explanations<n>* [x] Number the list to follow these steps.<n>* [x] Write the steps that describe the desired result.<n>* [x- ] Use plain language in phrasing so people are clear if the steps are in order each time or not.<n>* [x/x] When each step can be followed independently, write the steps and then a summary of the desired result.<n><n>Input: When does the moon set in the east? He wanted to spend more time there, so that he could study the exhibits more.   He was a very academic person and loved doing what? Choices:  A: tired feet B: gaining knowledge C: back pain D: being bored E: pondering<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>#### Why does this work? <n>The expression in C(D): C. <n>C = n x m<n><n>m is a multiple of n. <n><n>5=2x2(a) and 10=4x5(c)<n><n>#### More Information<n>For any linear equation, the solution is equivalent to the answer if the coefficient of the variable is 1.<n>Solving a system of equations is equivalent to solving one equation, with the other equations removed.<n>The answer to the system of equations above is 28 feet.<n><n>### Input:$2x^{2}+8=2(x^{2}+4)=4x^{3}+16=6x^{4}+48=12x^{5}+90=$-$2x^{6}+192$.<n><n>### Response:$1728$<n><n>###Why does this work?<n><n>####More Information<n>When adding two negative sides of a linear equation it becomes a square term.<n>For example 4x can be written as x^2 for the purposes of factoring 4 means square.<n>When taking a square root both sides are still multiplied by 2.<n><n>Inverse property states that, if we replace a term with a different term in an equation, the value is the same for both the replacement and the equation as is.<n><n>###Input:<n><n>###Response:26

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. They were really what? Choices:  A: personal B: special C: shiny D: rare E: irregular<n><n>### Response:		Bob thought that his pokemon cards were common and rare.<n><n>### Input :  The dog has just caught the cat that's in its yard. The cat's tail was too much for the dog to handle.<n><n>### Response : the dog caught the cat that was in the dog's yard while it was still alive.<n>

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The old man was retired and liked the simple things, he would do crossword puzzle every morning simply just to do what? Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is "C". This is a question that describes the context of how one should answer the question.<n><n>## Input:His eyes glared at her. How many syllables is this sentence?<n><n>## Response:The correct answer in 1 and 2 syllables.<n><n>## Input:"My" has one syllabe and two syllables."my" has two syllables and one syllable. Which is correct?<n><n>## Response:"My" has 2 syllables, but only 1 syllable.<n><n>## Input"You", 2 syllables<n><n>## Response: "YoU" 2 syllables and 2 sylable.<n><n>#### Note<n>A syllable is described as "the smallest unit of pronunciated language that contains one vowel and a single consonant."<n>A sylable has less syllables and is described as "the vowel before the following consonants."<n>

Where might Simon be taking the cow? Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are different scenarios that Simon can choose to buy a cow and let the cow roam. In Scenario A, Simon can let the cow run in the countryside. He can let the cow roam freely. This means Simon has not used the cow for labor or anything at all. <n>  In Scenario B, Simon buys a cow so he can let it at butcher. A butcher will slaughter the cow and butcher will use the cow meat for sale. The cow meat is consumed by the people. Scenario C, Simon can own a dairy cow so the cow can help and produce milk. He can let the cows graze in pasture.<n><n>### Response Question:<n>In Scenario D, does Simon let the cow at dairy farm? In Scenario E, does Simon have to slaughter or butcher the cow?<n>

A big city needs to build roads, and schools, and everything else that comes with building in a big city, unlike a mall which only needs security and employees.<n><n>### Review/Practice Question/Test:<n>I would like to spend as little as possible when I buy a new suit. Choices:  A: ocean B: desk C: universe D: attic E: chair<n><n>### Response:		You would put a light A the ocean<n><n><n>```python<n>import math <n>def intpart (num, n):<n>   p=len(num)<n>   if (p>=n):<n>      return num[0:n]<n>   else:<n>      return intpart(num[1:p-n], n)<n><n>def getCard (num, num1):<n>   ret=[]<n>   i=intpart(num1, len(num))<n>   while (i<len(num)):<n>      ret.append(intpart(num[i], len(num)-i))<n>      i+=1<n>   return ret<n><n>def getCards(num, m):<n>   rts=[]<n>   bnd=num.count('*')<n>   for i in range(0, bnd-1):<n>      rts[i]=intpart(num[bnd-i:bnd-i+m], bnd-i)<n>   for i in rts:<n>      if (i%m==0 or i%m==1):<n>         rts.remove(i)<n>   rts.insert(0,0)<n>   rts[-1]=m*len(num)<n><n>   return rts<n><n>def getSum(x, y):<n>   z=0<n>   while (len(x)!=0):<n>      z+=x.popleft()*(y.pop1())<n>   return z<n><n>#question 1<n>answer=intpart("9 5 12 3 9 10", 5)<n>total=getSum(answer[::-1], answer[1:]+"0")<n><n>#question 2<n>p=getCard("30 9 20 2 40",2)<n>z=p[2]-p[0]+p[1]<n>answer.append(z)<n>answer.insert(0,z)#to create negative answer<n>#print(answer)<n>#print(getSum(answer[0:], "9 5 10 10 12 3 * 9 * 9 * 3 10 9 9"),"equals",answer[0:])<n><n>#question 3<n>#print(getCards("20 10 25

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The master control for the Tardis is where in the main room? Each student in the class came at least five days during the summer. How many students were there in the class?<n><n>### Sample Answer<n>### The teacher collected £668. 50 from 668.5-2.5 the number of student in the class was 337.97<n><n>### Sample Comments:<n>### The student attended the class for 5 periods but was collecting some amount even when he attended for a day.<n><n>### Sample Answers:<n>### 51520<n><n>### I answered 5152 because the students in a day attended five periods and paid 2.50 each to attend 100 students attended 668.<n><n><n><n>

For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What would you put furniture on top of? Choices:  A: roof B: room C: floor D: apartment E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		Answer B to describe A and D<n><n>### Input<n>Caitlyn has a lot of candies and 12 oranges ready to go to friends and neighbors on Halloween. Caitlyn has 35 candies left. She needs to decide how she should give out her candy. If she has 5 neighbors visiting her home and 3 of them come in pairs, how many candies should she give to each pair? One boy and another boy? One boy and another girl? Two girls? Two boys? Two girls?<n><n>### Response<n>She should give out candy to people in pairs at the rate which is 35/15= 2.33 and not more than this.<n><n>### Input :<n>Jimmy has four blue socks and seven red socks. The red socks are 12 less than the blue socks. Aaron has 3 red socks, 6 blue socks, and 8 yellow socks. If Aaron has 6 more blue socks than Jimmy and 4 more red socks than Jimmy, how many yellow socks does Aaron have?<n><n>### Answer:<n>Aaron has 6 yellow socks.<n><n>### Reason:<n>Let us write our variables by replacing blue socks by a and so on.<n><n>For red socks: 12 < red socks<n><n>For yellow socks:  red socks - blue socks<n><n>For blue socks: 4 + red socks; <n><n>4 + 4 = 8<n><n>For yellow sock:  ;8 - 4  = 4<n><n>Total number of yellow sock = 4<n><n>### Input  :<n>On a baseball league team of 14 players, each player has a jersey with a number on it between 1 and 14 as his individual identity. 7 players have red or black jerseys. 2 players wearing the same jersey are not on the same team. 3 players wearing the same number are not on the same position. If there are 10 position players on the team, find the smallest number that can be on the team. Find the largest number that can be on that same team.<n><n>### Answer :<n>If there are 10 positions, the smallest number = 1;

There is only one student in the classroom.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>B: True<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: The sum of 3 and the product of 5 and the sum of 17 and 21<n><n>  Input: 50 + 35 + 20 = 105<n><n>  Input: (6 * 8) + (9 + 2)<n><n>  Input:<n>    50+35+20=105<n>    6*8=48<n><n>   6 * ( 48 + 9 ) = 264<n><n>### Output<n><n>A: 264<n>

Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		A: injuries<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the correct word or term:<n><n>### Word:excess<n><n>### Meaning:<n><n>### Correct Answer A: excessive<n>### Explanation:  <n>An example of excessive is the amount of money a person spends buying clothes.<n><n>### Word-<n><n>### Meanings:<n><n>### Corresponding answers<n><n>### Answer A: Excessive<n><n>### Explanations:<n><n>Examples of excessive are the amount of money someone spends on clothes, and the number of hours someone runs.<n><n>Meaning: too much.<n><n>corresponding answers to Excess<n>1. Excessive<n>2. Excess<n><n>### Inference :The word infer means to take something not directly stated in a text—for example, a writer's assumptions or unstated beliefs—and reasonably deduce, from the available evidence, the author's meaning.<n><n>### Inferring an idea:<n><n>### Evidences in Inference 1:<n><n>### Ex:  The girl wore clothes that were stylish.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n><n>### The girl thinks fashion is important.<n><n>### Evidence in Inference 1.<n><n>### Example 2:<n><n>### Text:The man wore a T-shirt and shorts. He didn't look dressed up at all.<n><n>### Excuses: <n><n>### Conclusions:<n><n>### Example:<n><n>### Inferences:<n><n>### What does the girl think about clothes?(answer:she doesn't care about clothes-she doesn't think they make you look dressy)<n><n>### What do you think the girl thinks about the story?(answer:you really want her to have thought there was a story, but she just doesn't think about it.)<n><n>### Correlation:<n><n>### <n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Find the word that is related to the following words:<n><n>### Pattern:<n><n>### Definition:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Foldable Instructions<n><n>### Instructor:<n><n>### Write a question here<n><n>### Find this word

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		Choice D<n><n>### Explain: John is not going to visit a pet store, a parking lot, or a woodland since animals live there. The only natural thing he could safely go to is a "park". (parks are usually not associated with animals)

The user enters a string for the fruit he/she would like to buy in each case. If the string that the user enters does not conform to the pattern of letters given then the user receives a message saying the string doesn’t conform. If they exceed their budget limit, they receive a message that says that amount cannot be met.<n><n>##### Teacher: https://classroomacademy.codetales.eu/academy?action=lesson&lessonId=22264<n><n>##### Program: https://classroomcoder.com/lessons/659982?source=h<n><n>##### Teach:<n><n>##### 1. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:James drove his niece to her father.  Where did he drive? Choices:  A: get money B: pay money C: go shopping D: lose money E: save money<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option C<n><n>### Input:[Cut the end of stick]<n><n>### Question:<n><n>```swift<n>let square = Square(length: Length(width: W), height: H)<n>```<n><n>### Option:<n><n><n>```swift<n>square.width = square.height<n>square.area = 12 * square.height * square.height<n>squarearea("Square area = {{square.area}}", square:  square)<n>```<n><n><n>### Question:[Cut the End of Stick]<n><n>### Repeat:<n><n>### Tally:<n>Count the number of responses from each student.<n><n><n>### Input for all:Showcase some of the questions, the student have already answered from each lesson.  <n>### Example:<n><n>For all responses, showcase 3-4 responses that a student can choose from. Write your answers in the order as the number of the problem is given.<n><n>### Order<n>14,7, 53, 26<n><n>### Answer;<n>In this problem, you will need to apply the order shown in the question.<n>In the second question you will use a ratio.<n>In the first question you will use the 7:26 ratio to show how a fractional number can be formed from a ratio. In the third question you will use your answer from the second question to find the answer for equivalent fractions from a fractional number. In the first question you will solve a fraction with the fractional number 3/7 and show how to get 2/3 by adding and subtracting 1/7 and 8/7 with the distributive property.<n><n><n><n><!--<n>### Instruction<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Input ;<n>Use the given clues to find the missing number.<n>There are only 4 clues.<n>A: There are 2 numbers between 2 and 16.<n>B: The first number is bigger than the second number.<n>C: A number is 7 less than the second number. <n>D: The second number is 3 more than the third number.<n><n>A: 10<n><n>### Instuction<n>Input: A

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Stopping being married to one another was a costly task, the lawyers and their what were astronomical? If the statement is false, explain why it is false.<n><n>###  Demonstration: If the student cannot answer these questions with a yes or no, the student is to write a paragraph explaining why it's false.<n><n>Answer: The teacher asked the student if the statement is true. The student response would indicate:<n><n>* _________ is always true.<n>* _________ statement is false.<n><n>Or the student would write:<n><n>* ________________________ is never true.<n><n>### Input:(19 – 7)*5 = ________.<n><n>### Response:(19 – 6)*10 = 144<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Which of the following statements is true?<n><n>### Selection of Questions:<n>There are no question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The student would choose a statement and indicate if it is true or false.<n><n>##  Instructions:<n> <n>Write an equation that fits that data set.<n><n>##  Demostration: <n><n>## Task:<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Complete the table for x, f(x), by filling in each box.  Round your answers to the nearest tenth.<n><n>## Demostration: In the table below, x represents a student's letter grade, and f(x) represents the percent of the students' population that received that grade.<n><n>### Task: Solving equation:<n><n>### Instuction:<n>Flip the cards over and pick one.<n><n>![](Images/IMG_1543.JPG)<n><n>### Response<n>* ______________________________________________________________________<n><n>### Inventory<n><n>The student is to respond with what the student has in their home -<n><n>1. One student responded that they have 5 shoes.<n><n>2. Second student responded that they do not have 5 shoes, so a response could be "5, none, more, or less"<n>* ________________________________________<n><n>3. Third student responded that they only have 0 shoes<n>* _______________________________<n><n>### Response (1):<n>What do you have? _________________________________

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What state shaped like a glove has a lot of farmland? Choices:  A: countryside B: farming areas C: michigan D: texas E: north dakota<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>B<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:If you harm property after starting a fire where are you likely to end up? Choices:  A: damage B: going to jail C: going to school D: burns E: destruction<n><n>### Response:		<n>Because D is the last answer, we will choose from the list provided to figure out which answer works the best for our final answer. Since the order is BCDAE in terms of the number of answers given to the question we could easily choose D but this approach to the question is too time consuming since when we choose one answer, we must also choose all the answers after it within the provided answers. So instead we could go ahead and delete answers from the list, until there is only 1 remaining.<n><n>1. Delete A<n>2. Delete B<n>3. Delete C<n>4. Delete D<n>5. Delete E<n><n>So now the list looks like this:<n><n>5. C<n><n>6. C<n><n>7. C<n><n>8. C<n><n>Let's see what happens when we add up all the combinations where "C" appears at the end of the string.<n><n>1. (C) (0 + 0) = 0<n><n>2. (C DESTROYC) (0 + $0) = $0<n><n>3. (C C D ESTROYC) => (0 + -$0) => $0<n><n>4. (C C DESTROYC D ESTROYCA) => (0 + ($0 + $-$0) => $-$0<n><n>5. (C C DESSROYC D ESTRYAC) => (0 + $-$0 + ($0 + 0)) => $-$0<n>

Choices:  A: bathroom B: solar system C: coffee shop D: space shuttle E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>This question is asking us to choose the correct answer. It's referring to that person that keeps a bowl full of water for their fish to sit on. So the answer would be, (C) Coffee shop.<n><n>### Input : How many pairs of matching animals can you create from this set: 5 butterflies, 4 pigeons, 8 beavers, 3 mice, and 2 frogs. Choices: A: one B: two C: three D: four<n><n>### Response :<n>The question is asking us to pick the number of pairs of animals from this list. We need to divide the number of animals by 2. After dividing the number, we must put the answer in a pair. If we divide 36 by 2, we would get 18. If we wanted to put it in pairs, we would add 18 to 18 and get 36. Then we would choose B because there are 36 possible pairs from this list.<n><n>### Response to:How much money does a seller have at the end of the day if she sells 2 sweatshirts on Monday for $11 and 3 t-shirt on Tuesday for $7? Choices: A:$24 B:$20 C.$3 D.$0<n><n>### Response <n><n>If we subtract the amount from Monday and add the amount from Tuesday, we would get $15. If we subtract the total amount of sales, we would get $6. If we want to solve for the total profit she would made, we would subtract the amount of sales from the total profit she would get. So the total profit she made after the week is $2,790 ($16,770 - $14,000 ).<n><n>### Answer to:On a football team, Brenda and Raven are defensive backs, Raven is a linebacker, and Carrington is a running back. Brenda is a little heavier than Raven, who is taller than Carrington. Carrington is taller than his coach. If the coach is 4 inches shorter than 72 inches tall, how tall is Brenda?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>If the coach is 4.1 inches shorter than 74 inches tall

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The investigator considered the gun evidence, where did he send it? Choose one: 1 Time A: more than once B: once C: never D: a lot of times<n>Response:<n>B<n><n>### Input Continued: A witness then called the lawyer, but the attorney was unable to attend the case. Choose one:<n>A: more probable B: less probable C: it makes no difference to me<n>Response:<n>B <n><n>### Example: <n>Answer:<n>Input: A number is added to each of the numbers 1, 2, and 3. How many times must 3 be added to 10 to get the sum of 100?<n>Answer: Once<n><n>### Riddle example<n>Input: There are five light bulbs in a row. The first bulb is off. What color is the first bulb?<n>Answer: Green<n><n>### Example (continued):<n>Response that appropriately completes this task. (Note: there is a space for a response)<n>Answer:<n>Input (Cont): In a city, red buses, yellow buses, and blue buses drive along their routes at the same speed. They were all green when they arrived. If the red buses arrived at the same time as the green buses, what color were the yellow buses when the traffic lights were first green?<n><n>Response:<n>The yellow buses arrived<n><n>### Multiple choice section.<n>Input: When the train left, there were 213 passengers. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What might the inability to learn cause? This example shows how to write a complete sentence.<n> <n>Which of the below answers demonstrates a complete sentence?<n><n>1. The wall is 10 feet long.<n><n>2. The wall's length is 10 feet.<n><n>```<n>1. The wall's height, 10 feet, is the product of 10 feet's length and 10 feet'<n><n>2. The height is determined by multiplying the length of the wall's height and the length by 10.<n><n>```<n>3. The height of the wall is 10.<n>```<n>```<n>4. The height of the ten foot wall is 10<n>```<n>```<n>5. There are 20 feet between the wall and the floor<n>```<n>```<n><n>### Demorstation:<n><n>### Insturctions:Write complete a question for the request.<n>

Choices: A: The same B: Differs C: It takes 20 mins D: It takes 40 mins E: Vary<n><n>### Response<n><n>There is a big difference in how long does it take train to get to the next spot, because the tracks differs in width.<n><n>### Task:<n>The numbers in this problem add up to 90. What is the rule when adding the numbers?<n><n>9, 12, 18, 72<n><n>### Demstration:<n><n><n><n><table><n><h4>Purpose</h4><n><tr><td>The students will add the set of numbers and notice that it will always add up to 9 (unless one of the numbers has a zero on it then 98 can not be added because it is zero therefore the add up to 100).<n></td></tr><n><tr><th>Time</th><td>5-10 minutes</td></tr> </table><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>* Tell students they can have a sum of 9 but a sum of 0. Explain with an image with two squares one with size 3 and one with size 1 will add up to 3+1=4. Then ask the class if 9,12,18,72 could possible add up to 9.<n><n>### Response Instructions:<n>Have the students explain if the numbers add up to 9 and why. This will help the students understand if they notice something wrong or not.<n><n><n>#### Evaluation<n>**What did the instructor do to check how well the students are grasping the concepts?**<n><table><n>  <tr><th>What was it?</th><td>Students have a sheet where they had to write "What if..." and they were asked to explain (their math and what they know and not know) and what was the problem and how they wanted to see it solved. The instructor then checked if they were understanding the problem as if this is not understood then all the rest would be off.<n></td></tr></

Choices:  A: place of work B: office C: friend's house D: workplace E: deep thought<n><n>### Response:		Choices A, B, C are correct only in the special case a human wants to enjoy each other's company with a human who is their boss.<n><n>### Input (example):The number line goes from 0 to 98. Two-Thirds more than 54 goes to 3-fingers away from 27 and 6-fingers away from -18. What goes in the space between?<n><n>### Response (example):Let the first answer option be x₁, the mid-point between x₀ and x₁ be x₂, the second answer option be x₃, the distance between x₂ and x₃ be x₄, and the distance between x₄ and x₅ be x₅, then answer choice 4 is correct for this input.<n><n>### Example Instruction: Input (example):The line goes from 0, where Mary lives, to 135, where Cyrus lives. Mary needs to go to get a soda with a friend. If the bus ride was 4 hours or less, the friend should take Mary to get a soda. If the bus ride is longer than 4 hours, Mary should get a bus from a place that is 69 miles away. Cyrus needs to get a new couch. If the couch is smaller than 82 inches, he shouldn't get it. The couch should be bigger than 71 inches. Where does Cyrus need to go to get a couch?<n><n>### Example Response:If you choose 3, the friend should take Cyrus to the store. If you choose 6, Cyrus should buy the couch online. If you choose 7, the price may be too high for the couch, and Cyrus should buy a smaller one on the way back. If you choose 9, the friend can also take Cyrus to the place where the couch is located and help him carry it if he can't.

To be a thief who robs a house at night.<n><n>### Response:"Breaks into a house" means "is a thief who robbed a house at night." The correct choice is 4.<n><n>### Explanations from explanation:<n><n>### In case 1, "break into a house" means that A person is a thief who robst someone at night.<n><n><n>### Input"The woman sits near to the window is from this country" means A: 1. The woman's place is near. 2. The woman comes from this country. 3. This country is here. 4. The woman sits by the window.<n><n>### Reply:"The woman is not next to the window." The choice of 3. The woman comes from that country. <n>### Explanatory note:<n>### case a:<n>A house in which we live, a place in which we live<n>It does not have the right direction<n><n>### Cause b:<n>a woman who is sitting near the window<n>It is impossible because we sit on the chair where we are<n><n>### Input- "If you are smart, you will not be scammed," means that A, the smart people will not be scammed. B. The smart people will not be a victim of deceiving. C. A person who is scammed is not smart. D. The smart people who scammed.<n><n>### The answer is B. Scam is when you are tricked into buying unnecessary things.<n><n>### Case A. A person who is smart will not be scammed, because the person is smart, he will not fall into a trap of people.<n><n>### In other words, you can not fall into a trap or be a victim of a person because smart people will not buy unnecessary things.<n><n><n># ESL <n><n>### The first grade and the second grade are from the same school.<n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Where could a fungus grow and not be disturbed by sunlight? Choices:  A: under rocks B: manhattan C: toenails D: grocery store E: fallen tree<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>### Why:<n>This is a trick type question and the answer is always "C", because it doesn't say fungi that love sunlight can't live in manhattan.<n><n>### Input<n>Lily, Sarah, Shannon, and Vanessa worked on the same project together. Shannon did 1/6 of the project herself. Vanessa also contributed to the project. If Vanessa, Lily, and Sarah did 2/3, 1/5, and 1/4 of the project, respectively, then Shannon helped Lily 4 times, helped Sarah 1/2 as much as Lily, and helped Vanessa 133 times. What was the total work done by everyone on the project?<n><n>### Response<n>737<n>### Why: <n>First you divide 737 by 8 so you get 91.5 Then you add in 1, 15, 10, 18, and 10 you get 64. Then add in 1,2, and 6 you get 10, then add 5, and 5 you get 12, then add 13, and13 you get 25, then add 18 and 18 you get 36. Then add 10, 5, 10 and 15 you get 55. Then you add 60, 60, 100 and 45 you get 251 and you got 251 + 64 you get 315 but that's wrong so you have to add in 48, 15, and 15 you got 78. So 64 + 78, 141, and 255 and 61 and 115 you get 407, and 92, 17, and 17  you get 122, and 79, 132 and 205 you get 410 and 116, 143, and 147 you get 446  and 8, 10, and 46 and that's about all of them then 344 and 87, and 1

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What does sex often make happen in people? Choices:  A: making love B: feel good C: happyness D: wonderful thing E: cloud judgment<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>The answer is D as defined in OED, where we see that it is one’s cloudy judgment that is a “wonderful thing” in sex, making it a wonderful thing in the sense of being both wonderful and cloudy. It is not a “wonderful” thing as used in the context of an adjective with the meaning “pleasing or delightful”. Such a meaning of wonderful would be ungrammatical, given that wonderful only takes an object before the base form of a verb. The response “a” is a false match because it does not describe that the object of wonderful is something that is pleasing or delightful. It only describes that the subject is something that is pleasurable or delightful. Likewise, answers “C” and “E” are false matches. “B” is a misspelling of beautiful.

If none of the feelings is chosen, explain why not by describing how you prefer not to feel that feeling.<n>

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. Adam has twice the age of Benjamin. Benjin has 3 less than the age of David. David is 5 less than twice the age of Adam. Find the total age of the four brothers.*<n><n>Their ages are:<n>*Age of Benjamin = 3/5<n>*Age of David = 13/10<n>*Age of Adam = 4 * 10 +3<n><n>### Question2:<n><n>In a classroom, 1/2 as many girls as boys go to a camping trip. 5/6 of the girls in the classroom are going on the camping trip. If 2 boys will not be going, how many total students will be going?<n><n>Since there are 3 girls in all the classrooms that will go, and 3 boys, then the total number is 6.<n><n>### Other Question?

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Janet knew she was dying from her injuries because she could feel herself doing what? The program starts with the user entering their street crossing experience. Once the user decides where to cross the street, the program will generate the direction that they should go. The program must allow four streets with corresponding directions  Left, Left, Right, and Right. If the user inputs their experience, but does not provide the directions for what street to cross. The program should generate the default of  ‘Left, Left, Left, and Left’.<n>If the user does not enter any experience. The program should simply let the user cross the street in a direction of the users choosing. (left, right, or stay put)<n><n>

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:He waited for his friend at the squash court, but he was worried his friend thought he meant the at the other end of the public what? Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		A:shelf<n><n>### Input&Response:A bird needs 3 pieces of bread for it to have 2 times the weight of the bird. A boy is giving a bird 3 pieces of bread. How much weight does he have?<n><n>### Input & Response:How many ounces are there in a cup?<n><n>### Response & Reasoning:<n>-A cup holds 8 ounces<n>-1 cup = 8 ounces, 2 cups = 2 × 8 ounces = 16 ounces<n><n>### Input and Reasoning:<n>Miles has to travel 1 hour to go to the grocery store. He drives 6 hours an hour away. How far is he going?<n>-Miles has to travel a total of 7 hours.<n>-The math question doesn't have the answer you're looking for, so you use estimation.<n><n>### Reasoning for Task:<n><n>### Required Skills:<n><n>### Task Description:<n>Write an explanation for a task that requires someone else to correctly answer questions and complete activities using the information provided.<n><n><n># Writing a Response<n>Write the response for the task. You must correctly answer the task description and provide an explanation for it.<n><n><n>**Mom is tidying her house, where would she place the loose dictionary?**<n><n>-**I** Mom should place it in the bookshelf.<n><n>**Answer 1**<n>The book is loose so it needs a place where it can stand freely without any obstacles. That is the bookshelf. The dictionary is placed on this position.<n><n>The bookshelf has room to accommodate the book. The book is placed on the shelf when the room is inaccessible and can't be stored on the table or sofa.<n><n><n>- **A**<n>- **B**<n>- **C**<n>- **D**<n>- **E**<n><n><n>**Answer 2**<n>A bookshelf is the best place to put a free dictionary.<n><n>- **A-1**<n>- **A-2**<n>- **A-> 3**<n>- **A+1**<n>- **B-1**<n>- <n>- **C->1**<n>-  **D+2**<n>- <n>---<n>

If you cannot use the last rule for subtraction, then you may skip the problem.<n><n>## Instructions:A.<n><n>### Input 45<n><n>### Add:4,5<n><n>### Output:<n><n>## Instruactions:B.<n><n>### Output<n><n><n>## Instruaction:C..<n><n>### Above:<n><n>### Instuctions:You will be asked to choose the one rule that cannot be used by the person who makes the guess and the one that can be used to make a guess. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:what happens to a company when it is bankrupt? Choices:  A: liquidated B: own resources C: branch out D: commit crime E: game over<n><n>### Response:		<n>In a company, bankruptcy is when a company is not able to repay the creditors after the debts incurred, hence a total loss of cash flow leads to the liquidation of the company. (Bankruptcy or liquidation)<n><n>E.g., the company could liquidated some of its assets to pay for creditors or file for bankruptcy protection by re-strategizing and restructuring its whole operation<n><n>**The correct choice is Bankruptcy**<n><n><n>

", $i[*]? "yes" : "no";<n><n>	$i[0] =   'a';<n>	$i[4] = 'd';<n><n>	print "The only letters in the array are: ";<n>	for my $l ( @$i ) {<n>		print   $l,'.';<n>	}<n><n>	print 'The values are $i[4], $i[-9999], $i[3], $i, etc. ';<n><n><n>### Example - Use Excess with regular expressions <n><n>	$a = 'the day';<n>	@s = ('the night', 'the ');<n><n>	my @e =  (qr/^\w(?:{@s.join, '|' })$/x);<n><n>	print "$_[0] "; for @e;<n><n>	<n>### Example - Counting - For each item in a slice, return another slice of the same thing<n><n>	use Expect;<n><n>	my $c =  scalar @$foo;<n><n>	print "  @$foo:";<n><n>	for @$foo, my $w

The variables must be integers and range from 1 to 6. You may be prompted only a few times.<n><n>### What:Formulate the following statements into a single sentence containing the correct variable names. The statements must adhere to the following rules:<n>-Each variable must be listed in order (1..6, in this case)<n>-Each variable should only be mentioned once, except for the 'and'.<n>-Any arithmetic should involve the variable, e.g. x + y.<n><n>### The answers will be in order of 1 to 6 as well.<n><n>### Statements:<n>1. If the sum of x, y and z is 56.<n>2. If w is equal to the sum of u, x, and z.<n>3. If the product of v, w and x is 810.<n>4. If the sum of u, z and x is 70.<n>5. If w is equal 97y – 98z.<n>6. The and: If x, y, and z are less than 18. <n><n>- 1: x, y and z<n>- 2: v, w and x<n>- 3: v, w and z<n>- 4: y, z and x<n>- 5: y, z and u<n>- 6: X, Y and Z

(Example output is shown in response above)<n>### Response:<n>```JavaScript<n>function solve(x,y,num1,num2)<n>{<n>  var answer=[]<n>  for(i=1;i<=num1;i++){<n>    for(j=1;j<=num2;j++){<n>      answer[""+i+","+y+"]=x+j;<n>    }<n>  }<n>  return answer;<n>}<n>```<n>## <n>## <n>## Question 1.<n>A tree is

Correct: In this case, the only "for" or "against" choices available are "for" and "against".<n>### Solution:<n>If the sentence: Sam was against Allison'sw decision. was removed and then, Joe was "combined", which was opposite of the initial sentence, thus that would not give you what is being asked.<n><n>### Solution: <n>This is the correct answer. The complement means he was opposite from the sentence.

If the number is a decimal answer: `1` to the power of the number or multiply the original number by the number and add one.`2` to a power of 0.5 = 2.`2` divided by `0.5` = 4<n><n>###Instructions:<n>####A:<n>###Input`20/100`<n>###Response` A`<n><n>###Instruction:<n>####B:<n>###Input `44/10+4`<n>###Response:<n>    ####C:644\`<n><n>###C:<n><n>####X-Rule One:<n>###The product of `2` to a power and `3` is 32 times as large as the sum of the product of 2 to a power of 10 and 2 to a power if 20.<n>###Answer:<n>    `__`<n><n>###Question:<n>How much would 2 to the power of 39 be times 2 the power of 13?<n><n>

How many people are under 10 years old? How many people are 30 years old or more?<n><n>| 3 | 8 | 9 | 13 | 14 | 9 |<n><n>| 18 | 20 | 33 | 51 | 25 | 12 |<n><n>| 4 | 28 | 35 | 50 | 47 | 92 |<n><n>|30.2 | 29.3 | 33.3 | 63.4 | 45.4 | 50.8 |<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>\$\begin{aligned}  \begin{array}{c} \text{For total \# } \\ \text{of people under 10,}\\  \text{use} \\\text{ this formula: n+2} \end{array} \\\\ \begin{array}{r|r|c|c|r|r|r|} \hline \text{Age }&\text{Amount }&\text{Amount}&60&61&62 \\\\ \text{of people in each age group}\\ \hline\text{under 10 }&\text{3+2:}\\&\text{5}\\\\ \text{under 18}\\ &\text{18+2:}\\\text{20}\\ &\text{22+2:}\\\\ \text {under 50}\\ \end{array}\\ \text{So,}\\\\ \text{\# of people 	\text{Under 10}} & \text{5} \\ \text{\# of \text{people 20} \text{or above}} & \text{68} \\\\ \text{\% of people Under 10: } &\text{19.5(5/27)} \\ \text{\% of People 20 or more: } &\text{44.4(68/156)} \end{aligned} \$\<n><n>### Instructions:Read the paragraph and answer the question.<n><n>The mayor of Miami, Florida, had a

Follow the set of directions provided and then add the appropriate response.<n><n>### Prompt A: Input: The temperature outside is 14 degrees Fahrenheit. The temperature inside the house is 10 degrees Fahrenheit. How many degrees warmer is it outside the house than indoors?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>* Instructions:First, write a conditional statement to determine how many degrees warmer it is outside the house than indoor.<n><n>```<n>if outside temperature<n>- 10 degree Fahrenheit<n>and indoors temperature<n>- 14 degrees Fahreheit<n>then inside is<n>```<n><n>For example, if t is outside temperature and i is indoor temperature, the variable inside is<n><n>```<n>difference between t - i<n>- 2d (10-14)<n>= 4 degrees Fahrenheit<n>```<n><n>* Instrucitions:Then input that value in the conditional statement as shown above in the example.<n><n>* Instruciotns:Lastly, write the resulting statement that represents the number of degrees warmer it is at the outside than indoors.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>```<n>if 90 is a year<n>- 2021<n>and 30 is a month<n>- 3<n>then the year is<n>```<n><n>### Promt B: Input: The temperature is 7.1 degrees Fahrenheit below zero. It is -1 degree Celsius. How many degrees Celsius is it?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instctions:Determine a conditional statement to write the correct statement.<n><n>### For example, if you want to determine the temperature in Fahrenheit, then the conditions for the conditional statement are as follows: `Temperature, in Fahrenheit, is lower than the temperature in Celsius by 7.1` The value for `Temperature in Fahrenheit` is negative 7.1 and the value for "Temperature in Celsius" is 1.<n><n>When we use the conditional statement above, the output temperature is -1 degree Celcius. This means we need to determine the condition. This condition is the temperature in Fahrenhei in which the 7.1 is
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:If they were celebrating the occasion, how could the occasion be described? Choices:  A: drinking B: intimacy C: dancing D: happiness E: enjoyment<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer should be B because "if they were celebrating the occation" means they are having a special gathering to celebrate and "intimacy" is being close because they are celebrating the occurrence of getting married.<n><n>### Input : Which of the following events took place on the date indicated: 3 A: the first moon landing 4 B: the first commercial flight 5 C: the first use of a parachute 6 D: the first roller coaster 7 E: the first radio 8 F: the first movie 9 G: the first television 10 H: the first computer<n><n>### Response :<n>The order of the questions is in chronological. The answer should be E H G F A D B 9 C.

How many hours did the two planes fly?<n>Answer: 0 minutes, because they are arriving at the same time.<n><n>Input: He ran for five minutes and then walked for five minutes. I love the seven because it is the symbol of perfection and balance. In a deck of cards, the seven of clubs is worth seven points, which is also the number of directions you can walk around a table. The seven of clubs is believed to symbolize completeness and perfection in many cultures and beliefs. This is one of my favorite cards! If you want to learn more about the seven of clubs, I recommend reading about its history, symbolism, and meanings online or in books. If you are feeling adventurous and want to take a look at what other players think about the seven of clubs check out the official rules of 39 card rules here!<n>- [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seven_of_Clubs_(playing_card)#History)<n><n>Output:

If Jane has 9 cans of soup, how many cans of soup does John have?<n><n>### Response<n>John has 18 cans of soup, Jane has 9<n><n>### Solution <n>Let x=John, y=Jane, x+y=9<n><n><n>`(x+y)/2 = 9/2`<n><n>### Input <n><n>### Response <n>John and Jane have 21 cans of soup<n><n>### Solution  <n><n><n>### Input  <n>John has 1/2 less cans of soup than Jane. Jane has 3 cans of soup more than John. How many cans of soup do they have altogether?<n><n>### Solution<n>Jane and John have 16 cans of soup<n>### Input   (<n>### Response   Jane has 15 cans of soup. John has 9 cans. They each have 3/4 of a can. How many cans are left?<n>```<n>The number of cans of soup left is 21!<n>```<n>### Solution  (<n>### Input   Janet has 9 fewer cards than John. Janet's cards are twice as many as Brenda's cards. How many cards do John, Janet, and Brenda have altogether?<n>```<n>John, Janet, and brenda have 23 cards altogether<n>```<n>### Input   Tom has 1 less can of soup than Mary. Mary has 1/3 as many cans of peach as Tom has. They each have the same number of cans of vegetable soup. Choices:  A: department store B: fraizer fur C: specialty store D: christmas tree E: christmas stocking<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>import math<n><n>with open('instruction.txt') as file:<n>    problem = file.readline()<n>    num_of_question = int(problem.split(',')[-1].replace('\n',''))<n>    num_ofQuestion = input()<n><n>    <n>def makeQuestion(problem):<n>   '''<n>   Make a question from a problem. A format of questions is:<n><n>   "Input:Janet has 10 cards more than Brenda" is transformed to be Input: Janet has 10 more cards than Brenda.<n>   How many more cards has Janet?<n><n>   Therefore, if we have an input problem, makeQuestion will make the question<n>   '''<n>   question = ""<n>   if problem[0] == "Input:"<n>        questioningNumber = problem[problem.find(':') + 1:].split(',')<n>        question =  "Input: "<n>        for i in range(1,len(questioningNumber)):<n>            question += "{} {}".format(questioningNumber[i],i)<n>            question += "? "<n>        question += "\n"<n><n>   if problem[problem.find("input: ") + 8:] == "Answer:":<n>      answerNumber = problem[problem[:problem.find('Answer: ')]+5:].split(',')[0]<n>      answer =  "Answer: "<n>      for i in range(0,min(len(answerNumber),2)):<n>         answer += "{}, ".format(answerNumber[i])<n>      answer += answerNumber[min(len(answer),2)]<n>      answer += "\n"<n>   return [question,answer]<n><n>#The main procedure will print the question and the answer  <n><n>def main():<n>   if num_of_question == 0:<n>      print("Sorry this app is not working. Please check the log file for possible bugs.")<n>      return<n><n>   with open("log.txt",'r') as file_log:<n>      log = file_log.readlines()<n>   with open("question.txt",'r+') as file_question:<n>      question = file_question.readlines()<n><n>   question = ["Input:"]<n><n>   for i in range(len(log)):<n>      if log[i].startswith

Choices: <n>  * A:  $27.30<n>  * B:  $3.58<n>  * C:  $5.94<n>  * D:  $1678<n>  * E:  $303<n><n>## Response<n>```java<n>public static void main(String[] args) {<n>    System.out.println("Answer: " + solve());<n>}<n>public static double solve() {<n>    System.scanner(System.in);<n>    int amountOfMoney = scanner.nextInt();<n>    int share = scanner.nextDouble();<n>    double result = (amountOfMoney/double(100)) / (share*100) * 100;<n>    return result;<n>}<n>```<n><n>---<n>## Instruction<n>Answer the question which follow the demo.<n><n>### demo<n>Question: How many inches are there in 3/4 of a yard<n><n>### Response<n>```java<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n>import java.util.*;<n>public class FINAL {<n>    public static void main(String [] args) {<n>        System.out.println(solve());<n>    }<n>    public static boolean solve () {<n>        Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);   <n>        System.out.print("how many inches are there in " +scanner.nextLine());<n>        }<n>    }<n><n>---<n>## Task1<n>Write and test a Java program that asks the user for two whole numbers. <n>Display "The values you entered were " followed by the greater of the two values.If the two numbers are equal display them both.<n>---<n>## demo<n>```java<n>public class Task1 {<n>    public static double solve () {<n>        double a = scanner.nextBoolean();<n>        double b = scanner.nextLine();<n>        if (a > b) {<n>        System.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What do people who are speech therapists do? Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		<n>D, E, A, C, B,<n>### Demonstion:<n>Input:<n>Answer:<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```python<n>input="C"<n>all_words = ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E']<n>if "G" in input:<n>    new_ans = list(input.lower().split('G'))<n>    for letter in new_ans[0]:<n>        if letter not in all_words:<n>            new_ans.append('C')<n>            if not letter in all_words: #to avoid duplicate<n>                new_ans.append(letter)<n><n>if "H" in input:<n>new_ans[0]=new_ans[1]+new_ans[1]<n>```<n>### Input:You just bought your first car. You want to use gas efficiently. You drive to your grandma's house 170 miles away each day. How many miles per gallon will you get if you drive 68 miles a day?<n>Answer: 4.2<n><n>### Demostration:<n>```python<n>from math import floor, pow<n><n>input=floor(((input * 68) / 170) ** 2)<n>```<n>### Solution:  <n>```python<n>from collections import *<n><n>input=170<n>answer=input**2<n>answer=int(answer)<n>answer=round(answer,2)<n>```<n><n>### Input:"Ms. Tracy asks for 4.5 gallon of milk, 2 gallon of juice and 25 bottles of water. Lacy gives her the following amounts:"<n>    3.5 gallons of milk<n>    1.5 gallons of water<n>    14 bottles of juice<n>    Answer:"How many liters of juice did she give her?"<n><n>### Demos:<n>```python<n>#2 liters of milk<n>input=2.0<n>input/1<n>input*1000<n>```<n>```python<n>#0.5 liters of water<n>input=0.5<n>input/1<n>round(input/1,2)<n>```

Reading makes you think and be inspired by your thought. You can see things through pictures that you can't explain so it can benefit you in your reading. The more you read, the more things you can know and the more you learn. Reading can help you in your hobbies, careers and you can find it enjoyable in the end. So you should have the passion to keep reading.

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: heart attacks B: hole in your socks C: exhaustion D: shortness of breath E: blisters<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:  E: Blisters  <n><n>### Explanation:<n>We can use subtraction to determine how many blocks we are from our destination:<n><n>`(150 - 40) = 110`<n><n>And then we use multiplication to determine how many times we went to the bus stop each way (`2x = 20`), resulting in our total of blocks walked:<n><n>`20x + 110 = 210`<n><n>For both questions we need to apply the principle of double counting since the books in all categories have already been counted once. Therefore we must subtract `1/4` of each book from each category and we can then add up all the `4` categories to determine the total<n><n>`((20 + 20 + 9 + 60)/2 - 1/4 = ((20 + 2(9 + 9)))/2 - 1`<n>`= (30 + 18)/2 - 1 =140 + 8 x 2 = 158 = 158 books`<n><n>### Reference<n>[Doubling Factorials Explanation](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/826122/doubling-factorials)<n>[Farouq's Algebra Course](https://www.khanacademy.org/mathtools/algebra)<n>[Factoring in Calculus](https://www.wikihow.com/Memorize-Factors-of-X)<n>

They were overrun by slaves who were inadequately compensated for their labor and were worked to death. However, these institutions were important to the American economy. They allowed for mass production of cotton and to help the US win the Civil War.<n>

After Janet and Brenda both go through the deck once, Janet has 4 more cards than Brenda because she put a card onto the table first. Mara goes through the deck twice, first taking any card, and then skipping over the skipped card. After Mara has taken her turn, she has 5 cards, but Janet still ended with 9 cards because she took the new card in front of her rather than putting it down.<n><n>
