How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:A yard is made up of what? Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		The yard contains three feet, Michigan, the city, the subdivision, and three arm spans.<n><n>### Input/Response: What is 42 multiplied by (45/5)?<n><n>### Input / Response: When is April 12th 2025?<n><n>### Input : What is the name of the book you bought at your library?<n><n>### Response : I bought the book, "The 13 Clocks" written by James Thurber.<n><n>### Output: Show me something in the house.<n><n>### Response  : Show me something in the bathroom.<n><n>### How much does it cost to take a walk on the moon?<n><n>### Cost in dollars = Cost in dimes + Cost in nickels + Cost in pennies<n>

Choices:  A: play chess B: sun themselves C: wrong house D: set table E: gettable<n><n>### Response:		<n>Based on the input, in order to prevent any errors, children will first try to sun themselves in the backyard. <n><n>### Example Input:<n>If children get confused walking:<n>1. Where may they go?<n>a.A  <n>b. B<n>c. C <n>d. D <n>e. E<n><n>### Example Output:<n>If children get home confused, they will start playing chess in the library<n><n><n>### Example Rationale:<n>The first choice is A (play chess). It's one of the choices. So, we need not consider other options.  <n>After this we need not worry about other choices and can only proceed with choosing answer of where to go.<n><n>### The answer is: <n><n>C)   Children go the wrong house<n><n>### Example Commentary:<n>1. The response can be done with a loop, which will be repeated until reaching end of choice.<n>2. One choice is required.<n><n>### Example:Input:<n>3175557<n>Input:<n>869708645, what is 317551756<n>Answer: -37<n><n>### Example Instruction: <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: <n>17 + 14<n><n>If we write the input as it is, we will get the same output of value 31<n><n>Output:31<n><n>Input:<n>17 x 14<n><n>Answer:248<n>Input:<n>16 * 15<n><n>Answer:2<n><n>### Example Response:<n>The same logic we use for addition, which will not change the number so the answer will remain 31.<n>Since we need only multiplication, therefore we won't change it.<n><n><n>### This example problem is solved by the "If and else" condition and the "repeat and "If" control structure.<n>### What is the correct syntax to write the above code on the palette, using only a program editor and a monitor screen?<n>### Instruces:  Answer the question.<n><n>## Rationale:<n>The solution should be written in Python, not JavaScript. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:A strong laxative will help you keep what kind of bowel movements? Choices:  A: strongwoman B: cake C: regular D: weak E: fragile<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Choose how to respond.<n>1. Choose the option that correctly completes the request, and do not respond to the other choices.<n>2. Explain your reasoning.<n><n>### Example Response 1<n>A laxative that will help you keep B bowel movements.<n><n>1. A. I choose A because it completes the request and explains my reasoning.<n>2. The answer is A.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>When I think of a laxative, I think of something to help bowel movements be easier and more regular. "Keep" means you keep the bowel movements. To keep something means to keep it from being replaced by another. A can be replaced by B, C, D, or E. A is the closest correct answer to my thinking of a laxative.<n><n>2. The answer to this question is A.<n>A strong laxative is a bowel movement that should only happen once a week and should be very soft, so that the blood will get from your body faster. The question is asking how many times a week should they have bowel movements. Weak can be replaced by strong, so A is the least likely answer.<n><n>### Question:<n>This question has four choices. Choose the option with the correct response. Then, post your answer as a comment.<n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Why might a person take a vacation? Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		A: relaxation | B: good things in a life | C: admiration | D: own house | E: needs money<n>Input: The boy's family earns 90 dollars less than the girl's family per week. This means that the boy's family has 2 and the girl's family has 5 times as many dollars per week. If the boy's family gets 2 dollars each week, how much money do the two families together have?<n>Answer: 70 dollars and a half<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. I will go there with my friends and we will travel by road. My best friend, Vicky, is going to travel by road for 14 days while I will travel for 18 days in total. I am going to spend almost my entire vacation in Spain because when I reach there my friends are leaving. My other two friends will stay in Spain for a week only. Answer this question after solving the following arithmetic puzzle. The first number in each row corresponds to one day in the row.<n>Answer:<n>##### Day 1: 6 + 7 = 13<n>##### Day 2: 7 + 7 = 35<n>##### Day 3: 6 + 8 = 14<n>##### Day 4: 8 + 7 = 62<n>##### Day 5: 5 + 8 = 65<n><n>### Input and Response: Write three words that describe your home town. Choices:  A: satisfied B: unnecessary C: luxury D: sufficient E: extra<n><n>### Response:		The answer to the question asked should be: "A: satisfied." It should not be satisfied as you do not need it. This is because the word would is a word used to imply that a non present thing may exist in the future. However, using satisfied here implies that the non present thing does not exist. Therefore, it is inappropriate to use the word satisfied here.<n><n><n>### Input and Response: Below is a problem. Write the response: Input: Which of the following is best? Input: 44.45 ÷ 0.5<n>Answer: "A: 44.21". <n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice questions. <n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: If x is greater than 20 but less than 30, then x + 1 + 4 – 10 > 23. For every language, write code for how many and how much for three types of request. Submit one code block for each language you have written code for and include the prompts for each type of request when you submit. Write your responses for the same types of request in each code block. For example, with Python, Write responses for the input: *How many feet in a mile?* *How much is 1.98 dollars in Brazilian reais?* and *How many books are there in the English language?* and write your response for the input: *What is 2 feet?* in each code block.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Input: The temperature was 8 degrees Fahrenheit today.<n><n>Answer:<n>```<n>The formula (T)°F = (9/5)x(C)+32.<n>T = 8°F<n>T = 42/5x(C)+38<n>C = -4°C<n>C = -40/5x(C)<n>C = 8x(C)<n>0.036x(C) = 0.256<n>C = (0.256/0.036)<n>C = 7°C<n>```<n>### Example:Example:<n>Input: 20 kg = 44 pounds.<n><n>Answer:```<n>20 lb = 44 kg<n>20 lb = (2.2x44) lb = 88 lb<n>```<n><n>## Construct an object structure that represents the given data with 1-D arrays and 2-D arrays.<n><n>In the example problems, you are asked to create an object that demonstrates how to manipulate information, including objects, from arrays. Choices:  A: headaches B: bigger brain C: education D: growth E: knowing more<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:Select all answers you deem applicable below.<n><n>* If x represents 200 ml and y represents 1 ml, then if 0.75 less than x, what is y?   -> x = y - 0.75 (since 0.75 = 200 * 1/4)<n>* The width of a house is 3 times its length. The width is 40 ft and the length is 15 ft. What is the perimeter of the house?    -> 40 + 40 + 60 + 60 = 200 ft<n>* If x represents how much money a farmer has left at the beginning of the day, y represent the number of hours left in the day. If x = 4/5 of y, how much money will the farmer have at the end of the day?  -> 4/5 of the total number of hours * 100 = 2400/5 = 480.<n>* The volume of a bucket is twice the cylindrical volume, but only 1/3 of the total cubed volume. If the bucket has a height of 7 inches and a thickness of 22/7 inches, what is the bucket's capacity?   -> Cylindrical Volume = 2*(7*22/7) = 162/7; Total cube volume = 7*22/2; Capacity = 162+52/7=114.03<n>* Which of these is the greatest to the the least square root?   -> It is square root of 9 - square root of 2 - square root of 6<n>* If you have a bucket with 4/5 of liquid and you fill it with milk, at what proportion does it overflow?   -> 5/4<n><n>### Note:<n><n>If I had time I would have added the input for each question with the answer<n><n>

In this task you can use the 25000 unicode character for response, but in the real interview question they only provide 1500 characters. So you can use the rest 9500 unicode characters (15000/1500) for additional space.<n><n>### InputThe robot shockingly began reading book after book. It had apparently learned to read.<n><n>### Response<n>The robot shockingly began read book after book. It has apparently learn how to read.<n><n>> [!Note]<n>><n>> Answer is in the format :<n>><n>> ```<n>> The car shoockingly began to drive after its tire burst. The driver was driving without wearing helmet. The car has apparently driven without helmet. <n>> ```<n><n>> [!Tip]<n>><n>> Write the response in this format. This format was provided so that the reviewer can easily understand the response.<n>><n>> ```bash<n>> The car shockingly began to drive after it's tire burst. The car has apparently been driving without helmet.<n>> ```<n><n>* Response should start with the sentence which you are answering.<n>* The car is started to drive<n>* After this there should be a comma then put a colon (:)<n>* Then the response should be written describing the response and how it is related to the problem given.<n>* When the response is written, it should start with 'The car shockingly...'<n>* Then it should end with 'has apparently been driving without helmets'. So keep in mind :<n><n>> [!Notes]<n>><n>> - The response can be divided into two sentences.<n>> - The response should match the scenario given. If a response is found to be 'not applicable', you need to consider this task as 'failed' in the task.<n><n>### Example:<n>You can use the given example of input and response.<n><n>###<n>| Scenario | Response<n>| :--- | ---| <n>| The dog shockingly began to chase the horse after his ears had been cut off. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:A student wants to hear what the professor is saying, what does he do? For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The explorers found a central passage, much to their delight it led straight to the ancient buried what? Choices:  A: public building B: tomb C: arena D: large building E: treasure<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Exampl:<n>Input: In a school gym, there are 1/3 fewer boys than girls. There are double as many boys as girls who play basketball or football. If all boys play basketball, How many boys are there altogether?<n>Answer: 90<n><n>Input: There are 24 apples in a bag, and Jenny takes a third of them. Then there are 16 apples left in the bag. How many apples are left in the bag?<n>Answer: 8<n><n>Input: In each class there are 3 times as more boys as girls. In each class, there are 7 more boys than the number of girls in that class. If 25% of the class is girls, how many students are there in that class?<n>Answer: 74<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following questions as soon as possible.<n><n>### Exemplar:<n>Input: There are two boys and one girl in a room. How many people are there in all?<n>Answer : 3<n><n>Input: A train passes a pedestrian at an 8:1 ratio, so it leaves the passenger 9 minutes after the pedestrian sees it. If a passenger and a pedestrian waited on platforms at a station, how quickly would the pedestrian have to leave for the train to pass them on a level crossing?<n>Explanation: The time required for the train as calculated to pass the pedestrian is divided by the time it takes for the pedestrian and passenger to reach the level cross by a ratio of 9:1 (ratio of 1 pedestrian to 9 passengers and ratio of 4:5 train to pedestrian= 1/4=1/9). So the time required for the pedestrian is 4 minutes<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: In 4 hours, it will take 5 times as long for you to run around. If it took 3 hours for the person who runs around to complete the task, then in what time will you be finished?<n>Answer:48 hours

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The banjo finds it's history in the Caribbean, but it's probably most famous where? Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		The banjo probably wouldn't be discovered in any stores. It is more likely it was found by some people who like music.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The choices A, B, and C are specific stores that sell muscial equipment. The banjo was probably found by someone who liked music. Choices don't show what other places were likely to find it outside of the United States. The "united states" is more of a place, not a specific location at all. And the banjo was more likely found by nice people.<n><n>### Input:"Tamara has at least 2 times as many bikes as Gilda. How many bikes does each girl have if they have the same number of scooters?<n><n>### Response:"Tamara and Gilda have the same number of bikes if they have the same amounts of scooters.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>"Tamara has atleast as many bikes as gilda, and they both have the same number of socceres. Which is how many bikes they have if they both have the same amounts of socceres"<n><n>### Rational<n><n>Bikes and Scooters will multiply to a number of bikes<n><n>### Input "The train station is 5 1/2 miles from his office. If he takes a bus from his office to the train station each day, how much money does he save in a week because a bus ride costs $2.50 and a train ride costs $6?<n><n>### Solution: "The train station is an even better route to the bus if he has to take a bus to get to his office everyday. Even if the bus costs 2.50, he will still save 6-2.50. That is 3.50 in savings"<n><n>### Solution Rational:<n>Both travel the same distance using the same mode. Even if the bus cost 2.50 the train cost 6, the bus was still cheaper.<n><n>### A little more explanation on the difference<n>The solution was answered in the traditional way. I didn't realize it would be different from a response. The answer didn't use a different way of thinking. The solution is correct, but was not a response, it was an answer.<n>

You have been offered a coupon for X% discount. You are only allowed to use this coupon once on any item from D) to E. To earn the X% discount, the purchase price of any one item must exceed the retail price by X% of its original retail price. You can get either an appliance or a discount depending on which comes first. If you get a discount, the discount will come before you buy any appliance. For example, if you were planning to buy an iron, you could get either the discount or the iron before paying. If you ended up purchasing an appliance, but first you got the discount, then you buy the appliance for $98 (instead of the original $100).<n><n>### Expected output 1 (after getting the discount, but not the appliance): D) Oven.<n>### Expected Output 2 (after getting the discoupon, but not the appliances): A) Washer. <n>### Expected Input 1 (Wanting the discount before wanting to buy any of the appliances)<n>If discount > 5: D) Oven. <n>If discount > %40 to get the discount: A) Washer <n>If discount is just getting X%: C) Microwave.  <n>If discount is not getting X%, but is at least 18%: B) Refrigerator.<n><n>### Exploration<n><n>```python<n>print("You

He lacks the means to balance the cup.<n><n>###  Instructions:Answer each of the following questions.<n><n>## Demo:<n>Input: 5 dogs and 5 boxes of dog food.<n>Answer:<n>20 boxes of dog food and 5 of those boxes will equal 7 dogs or boxes of dog food. That leaves 5 dogs and 20 boxes of dogfood. Dogs eat 1 box of dog food a day, so 5 dogs will get 5 boxes of dogfood a day. Now, 20 boxes of food is divided by 5 dogs and that is 4 boxes of dog food per dog, every day. That means the dogs can eat the 20 boxes of boxes a day, every day without worry.<n><n>### Inputs: The woman bought one of every item on the grocery list. How much did each item on the list cost?<n><n>### Demo<n>The total cost of the grociries was $454.00 10% of $454.20 is $45.40 and the woman bought all items on the grocieries list.  She spent $45.44 for each item on the list.  The woman ended up spending $454.44 on grocieries for the entire transaction.<n><n>### Note:<n>The woman bought one of every food item, and they all cost the same amount.<n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Where is a bald eagle safe? E) 78 inches.<n><n>```<n>A -> 67 + 14 = 81 which is less than 91 inch<n>B -> 67 +14 + 18 = 97 which is less than 78 inch<n>C -> 67 +30 + 16 = 113 which is more than 78 in inch<n>D,E -> None of the above<n>```<n>

How much distance is Alli? Choose (3 steps ahead of Beta) (72 feet ahead of Bets) (53 feet ahead Casey) (119.8 to 160.71 metres away from all.<n><n>### Input-<n><n>A. 177 feet<n><n>### Response-<n><n>3 steps ahead of Betsy<n><n>### Input:-<n><n>A. 58 feet away<n><n>### Response:-<n><n>72 feet Ahead of Casey<n><n>### ANSWER:<n><n>Alli is 177 feet away, 72 feet ahead of casey, 53 feet ahead of casey<n>*<n>*<n><n>### Input3 -4:<n>7 peoples were walking to lunch Ally is 3 steps away from betsy who is 56, casey is 40 steps ahead of chlo who is 13. Chlo is 10 steps behind ella who is 45 steps away from all others.how far is Ally<n>*<n>*
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What will happen to skin pinched in something? Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is B: feel pressure<n><n>### Reasoning:The author said that skin pinched in'something' will feel like pressure. Since that is true, the other choices are impossible.<n><n>### Input :Why did the student use more math than the first student? Choices A: He is older than her B: He has a lot of practice C: he used a complex equation D: He used a calculator E: He needed it for homework<n><n>### Response : The correct answer is E: He needed it to his homework<n><n>## Task:<n>### Input:If the student A and student B can finish a given task in 4 hours, how long will it take student A and student B to finish that task in 2 hours?<n><n>### Input 2: If the student A and student C can finish A given task in 3 hours, how long will student A and student C finished that task in 4 hours?<n><n>## Task Solution:<n>### Input 1: 6<n><n>### Input2: 6<n><n><n>## Task <n>Find the difference between the two input.<n><n>## Input:<n><n>## Response :<n><n>## Task 2<n>Find the average between the first 2 input.<n><n>##  Input:<n><n>

Choices:  A: box B: home C: alley D: lap E: barn<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>(A) <n><n>### Question:1.<n><n>Input: Janet and Brenda are playing a card game. Janet has 4 fewer cards than Brenda. If Brenda has 46 cards and Janet has 42 cards what is the total number of cards that they both have?<n><n>2.<n><n>Input: There are 11 red apples in a basket, 5 green apricots and 2 purple pears. Marcos picks 5 red apples, 3 green apriocots and 1 purple pear. How many apples are there in the basket?<n><n>### Question 3:<n><n>Input: Efren, Hafiz, and John are eating a whole cake between them. Efren eats 1/2 of the cake and Hafiz eats 3/7 of the cake. John eats a bigger piece than the rest of the cake. If Efren and Hafiz divide the remaining cake equally how much does John have left?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>**Instruction:** <n><n>1. Janet and Brenda have 9 cards less than Brenda. Brenda has 4 less cards than Janet. They have 10 cards more than Janet. <n><n>**2.** Marcos picked 5 red apples from the basket. There were 5 red apples and 3 green apricots in the basket. <n><n>**3.** It says efren, hafiz and john ate a bigger piece than the cake leftover. It's unknown whether this means John had the most cake leftovers or he didn't have any leftovers. If it meant he had the most leftovers I would multiply the quantity of cake remaining by 1/3 and multiply it by the quantity of red apples taken by Brenda (5x2/3). But I don't know if that satisfies the instructions given. <n><n>### Input<n><n>The following is the data from a t-test. Please use statistical methods of your choice to verify the hypothesis. Choices:  A: mail box B: suitcase C: front door D: bowl E: post office<n><n>### Response:		<n>In class, students would have a hard time knowing that B,E, and D would be the right choice for letters that are delivered by hand. A and C being the wrong choice for letters delivered by hand.<n><n>### Input<n>Choose the letter that describes the order in which you solve equations presented here.<n>A: B C D E F G H<n><n>Your Answer:<n><n>### Response<n>Students were presented with:<n>A) I would start and solve a problem from least to greatest and see what the answer is.<n>B) I would start and go down the letters one by one and see what i get as the answer.<n>C) I would make sure to do it in correct alphabetical order.<n>So I would start B,A,C,E,G,F,H<n>D) I would pick and solve a random from most to least.<n>E) I would pick the easiest and solve from most to least.

Monday<n>B. Wednesday<n>C: Tuesday<n>D. Saturday<n>E. Friday<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input x:<n>Choices: x=14<n>x=25<n>x=8<n>x=22<n><n>### Response x<n>Choices: A 1x+2y=18 then y=14<n>B 3x+2y=35 then y=8<n>C x=3y=22 then y=3<n>D x=7y+3a=54 then y=3<n>Answer: C<n>

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Where would someone learn to play an upright piano? Choices:  A: music room B: music store C: music class D: medium E: house<n><n>### Response:		Which answer would be the best choice?<n><n>C<n><n>### Reason & Evidence : <n>We can't really learn to play an uptight piano in music class because uptight pianos are harder to play than a regular piano.<n><n><n>

Choices:<n>  A: feeding a squirrel<n>  B: feeding your cat<n>  C: giving it to someone<n>  D: having an orange juice<n>  E: eating fruit leather<n><n>### Input2<n>If you're counting the cars on the road, you're probably doing  what?   Choices:<n>   A: counting to 10<n>   B: counting to 15<n>   C: counting to 18<n>   D: driving<n>   E: reading<n><n>### Insturctions:<n>You can only answer one of the questions. If you answer both questions, then it's double zero.<n><n>### If your answer to the first question was D, then the answer here is A.<n> <n><n>### If you answered B the correct answer was A.<n><n>

Jane, the older one, is wearing a purple dress. The other one, Jack, is wearing a maroon jumper. Jack has black hair and Jane has light brown hair. Jack drinks orange juice and Jane drinks hot chocolate. Which friend is the older one?<n><n>### Response1:Jane<n><n>[![](http://icons.iconarchive.com/icons/codyhuntington/baskbook/48/BW-Book-146900.png)](https://github.com/codyhunts/CodingInterviewPreparationGuide/blob/master/questions/0721.md)<n><n>### Response2:Jack<n><n>[![](./07212.png)](./0721.png)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following question.<n><n>You have been asked to solve a complex math problem while in the bar. You answer the question correctly, but you are asked to explain your solution. Write a narrative that describes the steps involved in your solution. Make sure you use the mathematical terms, operations, and symbols associated with the solution.<n><n>### My Solution:<n><n>### Input1:Let's solve a question of area.  The problem states: The length of a soccer field is 400 feet. (Let x be the length of the soccer field.) What is the area of a soccer field that's 400 feet long? If x is 360 feet, what is the area? If x is 4000 feet, what is x? Input2:Let's solve similar to problem above.  The problem states:"Tom used a measuring tape to measure the area of his kitchen, and he got a result of 9 square yards. (Let y be the area of the kitchen that Tom measured.) What is the area if the kitchen is 20 square yards? If y is 120 square feet, what is a quarter of y? If y is 5
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to achieve when talking to someone? Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n><n>### Response:		I hope we can improve our relationship, by talking about each other's issues and helping understand each other better. A: communicating with one another B: hurt feelings C. D: intimacy, to become comfortable with one another E: changing behavior<n>

Choices:  A: flower B: animal C: flower petals D: vegetable E: alive<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is Choice:   <n><n>### Input<n>- This is a sample of a 4th grade writing test multiple choice. <n>- Choice A contains 4 examples of antonyms from the list <n>  - incompetence, success, objectionable, success<n><n>- Choice B contains 2 examples <n>  - inoffensive, incompetent<n><n>- Choice C contains 9 examples of synonyms from the list: <n>  - impractical, agreeable, irritation<n><n>- Choice D contains 2 examples of hyperbole from the list: 1. The cat and the dog ran to each other. 2. If your brother was any more annoying, he would be perfect.<n><n>### Response<n>- Of the 4 choices, Choice A has the correct number of antonyms.<n>- Choice A has 4 examples of antilogy  <n>- Of the 2 choices, Choice B contains the correct number of antilogy <n><n>### In this question, Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda and Mara has twice as much cards as Janet.<n>What if Janet has 40 more cards than 150 and Mara has 41 cards less than 141? How many cards do they now have in all?<n><n>- Of the choice Janet has 9 less cards than Brenda and Janet has 41 more cards than 141.  <n>- After being asked the second time, Janet has 8 more cards than Brenda  <n>- Mara has 50 less cards than Brenda<n><n>### Janet's correct answer is 71<n>- Janet has  6 cards more than Brenda and Mar a has twice as much cards than Janet.<n><n>- Janet has 4 cards more than Brenda<n><n>- Mara has  45 more cards than Janet<n><n>### Answer: 71

When combined, what percent of people have at least one of the things? Choices:  D: 90% B: 25% E: 12% C: 50% A: 68%<n><n>### Response :<n>In the example shown what is the best way to calculate the number of people who own a home and car.<n><n>### A question :How many women are in a classroom of 25 students if 30 percent of the students are women?<n><n>### A solution : First break the two questions into two different problems that are independent.<n><n>### The first problem is 30% of 25 = 25/30 = 8/3 = 8 women/30-5= 25-8= 17males.  The problem can be reworked to be 100% of the classroom by multiplying 8 by 3.<n><n>In this case the total number of students in the classroom is 30+17, which equals 50.<n><n>### Question :  In a classroom of 30 students, what percent are girls?<n><n>### Question:  In a classroom, each student is represented by a specific number from 1 to 100. What is the combined total of all the numbers of the 40 students in the classroom?<n><n>### Solution : The number of students in this classroom can be broken down into six different problems. Each problem has equal parts that can be added together. <n><n>Each problem can be broken down into its own section which is the same for all problems. <n><n>1: 20 of the students are equal to 20%<n><n>2: 15 of the students are equal 15%<n><n>3: 20 of ths students are equal to 1/5 of the class (which is 4 students)<n><n>4: 7 of the students are equal tp  1/8 of the classroom (7/100 in numbers)<n><n>5: 35 students are equal to

Choices:  A: toy store B: bar C: casino D: table E: family room<n><n>### Response:		I was playing at A with my three mates.<n>### The solution we will use is the "Which one of the following..." approach. You should be familiar with this type of question from school.<n>### What makes this approach work is that the question-writer supplies the information to answer the question, but in an unusual manner.<n>### If we analyze this approach, the question becomes a game of "True or False." We are told that Leila has 2x the number of viewers as Voltaire, and we are told we don't know if they earn x, so Voltaire will earn x/2 and Leila double that.<n>### The information says, "Per week," which means 52 weeks per year. Now, we know that x/2 * 52 = 260/2, so if Voltaire gets x/2 he will earn $130. That means Leila will earn $350 if she earns $x per week. It would be best to answer with two sentences as the solution will allow:<n>### (1) Voltaire earns $130 per week, and<n>### (2) Leila earns $350 per week.<n>### It's that simple.<n><n>### The solution:<n>### I have a job interview tomorrow.<n>### The interviewer will ask me this question:"What makes a good teacher?"<n>### I will say:"If a teacher has patience, a kind heart, and loves to see her students learn and understand new topics, then she is probably a great teacher."<n>### I hope my answer will be the answer of the job interviewer.<n>### The best candidate for the job should have these qualities:<n>### (A)patience (B)kindness (C)understanding (D)love(E)patient(F)understanding(G)kind (H)all of these

Choices:  A: condition heart B: expend energy C: laugh D: stretch E: weigh<n><n>### Response:		Stretch<n><n>### Input<n>Jesse and Zara own a small vending machine business. If Jesse sells $60 of products per day, how many days will he need to sell at least $300?<n><n>### Response<n>If Jesse sells $300 in a given day of his business, the profit is $60. We have to find the number of days that we will reach $300.<n>To do so, we have to multiply the number of days $/60 in order to find the daily profit and we have to put $60 in the second place in order to have the total profit then we can substitute numbers for every variable and we obtain the following equation $d/60=60 so d=60 and $d+60=60. So $d=0.<n><n>### Input <n><n>A crane operator moves cinder blocks. It can lift 100 lb at a time. It takes 200 block to build a retaining wall. The operator can only lift each block once. How long it will take to build a 200-block wall?<n><n>### response<n><n>We can find first the number of cinder blocks to make the 200-cinder blocks wall, it is 1000 then to find the number of blocks to lift to build the 200 layers we go to subtract $100$ in order to have the second layer to lift and we have to find 4 more 100 in order to lift these cinder blocks into the fourth layer<n>$$1000-100-10-0 = 4 x 100 = 400$$<n>So we will have $1000-400$ cinder block layers to add <n>```math<n>=600 cinder blocks<n>=16 cinder blocks per operation<n>=4 lifts per cinder blocks<n>=4 lifts x 100 blocks per crane lift operation = 400 crane operation<n>=5 crane machines and will be $5555$<n>5+5=10$<n>```<n>I could have divided $1000$ by $100$ and i get $10$ to have it a little easier. But it is the same thing

Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:A blowfish lives free. He lives on his own. Where does he live? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Where might I find unusual varieties of roses? Choices:  A: botanic garden B: flower garden C: backyard D: supermarket E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Explain:It is a good question, as roses are famous for their colourful blossoms that come in different colours. The question then aims to test the respondent's knowledge on where to find unusual varieties of these roses. Hence, choice D is wrong because it indicates a supermarket, where it would be unlikely to find such varieties. Likewise, answer choices A and C are wrong as botanic gardens are botanical gardens, and they contain all sorts of plants. Flowers are plants, but they're not botanical, and this is the purpose of flower gardens. Choice B would suggest places other than rose gardens. Answer choice E is correct as 'outdoors' refers to the outside, and since roses are plants, they will grow outdoors.<n><n>### Exercise:How many gallons of oil does a 1999 Ford Expedition hold?<n><n>```javascript<n>2 rows 8 cols<n>[["gallons","1999","ford"]<n>,["expedition"]]<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Add an answer for the "outside" to the table in the exercise above.<n><n>### Response<n><n><img src=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SirDentZilla/Mathematics/main/files/instruction1.jpg><n><n>### Explanation<n><n><img src="https://raw.github.com/SirFunkyD/Mathematics/master/files/exercise.jpg"><n><n>### Instruct:Enter the correct number of gallons of oil for the given "outside".<n><n><img src><n><n>### Response <n><n>4.6<n><n>### Instuct:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration<n><n><img source><n><n>### Instrutction:Answer the following true-false question.<n><n>## Exercise<n><n>```javascript<n>3 rows 3 cols<n>[["true","false"]<n>,["question"]]<n>```<n>```javascript<n>3 cols 2 rows<n>[["question","answer"]<n>,["question2"]]<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How  many cards do they  have  in all if  Mar a has 40 cards  less than 15 0.<n><n>### Mara has more cards than Janet by 1 card, they each have 3 cards less than 143 cards. The difference between Mara and Janet is 150 - (3 + 3), so the remaining 143 cards = 143+150-3-3 = 143 cards<n><n>### B) Pete walked 5  blocks  from  his   house  to  the bus  garage in Houston. Choices A: study C: ask B: discuss philosophy C: learn E: play<n><n>*The question contains a "misplaced modifier".*<n><n>**Example:**<n>>**"When the doctor checked Mara, he said her lungs felt healthy and her eyes looked better."**<n><n>In this sentence, "he said her" goes with the wrong person. The "he" is an action being done by the doctor - he spoke to her.  The next word, which should go with the correct thing, is "eyes", and the eyes are her.  The sentence should read "When the doctor checked Maras eyes, he said her lunch felt healthy."<n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		**Answer: E**<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input:In a classroom, there were 12 more chairs than tables. The chairs were 1/3 as many as the number of boys in the class. There were 40 more desks than chairs; if the number of desks was twice the number of girls in the class, how many desks were there?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>(12 × (12 + 40) - 40) ÷ 3 = (172848.25 - 40) /3 = 172844.0875 ≈ 1728637.5 / 3 = 579883 ≈ 579890<n><n>### Explanation<n>First, we subtract one from the number of desks. Then we subtract another to get the answer.<n><n>### Input  <n>Input: 45.759394 feet of wire were wrapped in the shape of a circle with 139 turns. If the diameter of the circle was 14.269373 meters and the radius was 7.464142 meters, what was the thickness of the wire in centimeters?<n><n>### Solve<n><n>First, we subtract<n><n>Next, we use the formula for the Area of a Circle [A=πr^2], which leads to the following in the case of the given problem:<n>Pi = 3.1416, r is the radius of the circle which has area π r². Here r = 7.46, so π r² = 50.573221 cm²<n><n>Since 45.769394 feet is equal to 14.063383 yards, we use the following to find cm: 45.6 square feet ÷ 0.09144 square yards = 500.4949494 sq cm<n><n>

Choices:  A: heart transplant B: distance himself C: perform surgery D: study medicine E: let blood<n><n>### Response:		The answer to this question is C: perform surgery. A patient who needed a blood transfusion from a healthy person might be given a donation of leeches instead.( https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/let_(blood))<n><n>Leeches would be used in a blood transfusion for a medical procedure such as heart transplants that need regular blood transfusions.<n><n>A leech was a blood-sucking worm believed by old-time doctors to draw blood and toxins from the body. If the ancient physician tried to treat this patient with leeches, the patient would drown or die of septic shock from multiple bites to the same site. This was what happened in a medical "study" conducted by a physician called Ambroise Pare, a French surgeon in the 16th century, who was the last person to drown after using leeches as medical treatment.<n><n>### Input -1: How many times faster is 1 1/4 furlongs equal to 1 1/2 miles?(Choices: 2 furlongs, 4 furlongs, 8furlongs, 1/2 mile, 3/4 mile)<n><n>### Response -1: -1/4 furlong is one-eighth as fast as a standard furlong.<n><n>Multiplied by a factor of 1 in 3, we get the answer of 2 1/2 as furlongs of 8 (since 1/4 f = 1/8 of 16, and then 2 1/4 f or f = f.  8 =  20)<n><n>### Input 1: What do you get when you multiply 3/5x0.125(3/5).125?<n><n>---<n>175 0 12,5 175.0<n>250 125.0 0 250.0<n>125 175 175,0 0 1 1/ 5 . 12 5 0 1 250 1 1 1.000 125 1 1.1250 175 00

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The delivery man was delivering a whole crate of shampoo, they went through a lot of it at the what? Choices:  A: supermarket B: motel C: at hotel D: shampoo bottle E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>There are quite number of ways you can get this right but you are expected to answer in a coherent way.<n>### Input:<n>What could the answer be?<n><n>Input:The delivery man was not carrying a lot of crate of shamppoo. Choices: A: carrying B: delivery man C: 14 D: not a lot E: 13<n><n>### Response<n><n>You can have different ways of expressing your response correctly.<n>### Instruction<n><n>Input:In a survey, 39% of adults said they drink coffee. Among that group, 10% said they drink more than 6 cups a day. How many adults in a survey drink more than 6<n>(Coffee cups a day?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>39% of Adults drink coffee while 10% drink more than 6 coffee.<n><n>There are 341 adults drinking coffee and 13 drink more than 6 therefore 354 adults drinking it.<n><n>### Input<n><n>How many more people in a survey drink coffee more than 8 cups a day? Choices: A: 450 people B: 600 people C: 750 people D: 1,000 people E: 1,200 people<n><n>### Response.<n><n>There are many ways you can get this correct but you are expected to respond in a coherent language not repeating words and in the right order.<n><n>You can use these formula to get the answer you are seeking.<n>$$<n>Number of Survey = 354 + 13 <n><n>Number of Survey drinking more than 8 cuos = Numberof Survey * 13<n><n>Therefore, A = 354(10%) + 13(10%) = 390<n><n>Therefore, option A is Correct<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>There are 151 guests in the auditorium. What fraction of them can sit in the second row? Choices: A 5/6 B 15/14 C 5/14 D 1/3 E 5/10<n><n>### Demotstration<n><n>Auditorium = 15

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. What is the number?<n><n>### Response A: 26<n>### Response B: 13<n>### Response C:10<n>### Response D: 32<n>### Response E:52<n><n>### Choice 1. What is 4 less than a number subtracted by 7?<n><n>### Choose the best answer C:8<n><n>### Two plus three equal four times four equals five minus two.<n><n>### Choic 1. Two-hundred minus eight equals four hundred times three. Plus seven equals two hundred twelve.<n><n>### Answer: The first six integers in a sequence are chosen freely from 1 – 7. The next six integers are also chosen freely from 1 7, but they must use one less digit than the first 6 digits from 22689128<n><n>### Response B. A fraction is two-thirds of a whole, a whole is a quarter of two-thirds.<n><n>### Response C. A third of a quarter is<n><n>### Response D. A third of a third is<n><n>In order to know your answer you have to know if 4/3 can be divided by 3/3<n><n>### Response G. The fourth and fifth numbers of the series below add to 4. Which two can be divided into two units?<n><n>### Fourth Number:95<n>fifth number: 90. 90/2 = 45/2<n>95/2 = 47/2 so both 90 and 95 can be divided by two units.<n>

This means in rooms the kitten is allowed to climb things, but not the bedroom door, when the kitten goes to bedrooms, its owner keeps the bedroom door opened. This means that when the kitten goes in rooms it is allowed to the bedroom, but they have to unlock it.<n>### In-Class Support Needed: Yes - need support<n>### Feedback Requested: (Optional) I'm not sure this is correct<n><n>### Helpful Hints Feel free to ask me if you have any questions or need help.<n>

Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input & Response:<n>Janet has 9 cards Brenda &amp; Mara have twice as many cards as Brenda& the total number of cards Brenda& Mara have together are 150. Janet's cards are 150, 152, 154, and 155. Brenda has more cards.<n><n>1. Brenda has 95, 97, 98, and 99<n>2. Mara has 15, 12, 11, and 10<n>3. Janet’s total number of cards = 9 cards more than Mara’s<n><n>1. Total number of cards Brenda and Mara have together is 150<n><n>2. Brenda 20 > total number of cards Brnda and Mara have together and that number is 150. So Brenda has 30 more.<n><n>3. Mara’s total # of cards = 20 cards less than Brenda’s<n>4. Mara’s # of cards - Brenda’s # of cards = 30<n><n>5. Mara’s cards – 30 = 12 cards. So, cards of Mara = Mara has 10 cards + 12 cards = 22 cards total<n><n>### What have you done to earn a grade of C or better for this task?<n><n>### Question:<n>This questions tests if the user can determine if some operations were done correctly.<n><n>### Answers<n>Jan has 9 more than Brenda<n><n>    Jan: 16, 16<n><n>Brenda: 8,  8<n><n>  total: 24<n><n>If Jan has 9, Brenda has 8, then Brenda has 1<n><n>    Brenda: 10, -1<n><n><n>If Jan has the same as Brenda than we got 22<n><n>    Jan: -9, -9<n><n><n>Both numbers have to be the same to equal the question given: 22.<n><n>Mara and Janet have the same number of cards. Mara is 150 and Janet is 150 as well.<n><n>### Exercise 1<n><n>### Question

The goal for the audience is to see the victor. This is due to the fact that a viewer wants to feel happy for any victor. A viewer does not want to feel miserable because of a loss.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What feeling might propel one to instituting civil action? Choices:  A: complications B: tiredness C: anger D: trial E: court case<n><n>### Response:		The answer is option C.<n>

No further information given.<n><n>(b) Write F if those statements are false. No further information given.(c) 	The statements in part (a) and (b), if any, are independent of each other, i.e., either one is true or false no matter what the other is.<n><n>(a) There are 30 students in math class.<n>(b) There are 14 students in chemistry.<n>(c) 35 students in math class attend a math contest.<n>(d) There are 10 fewer students in math than in chemistry.<n><n>(a)*(b) There are  2 fewer students in chemistry than in math.<n><n>(a)(d) There are more students in math class than in chemistry. <n><n>(b)(d) Five more students are in chemistry than in Math.<n><n>### Response:(a) Answer either true or false. No further information is given.(b) Answer either false or true. No further information is stated.<n><n>(a){(1}{4)}<n><n>(b) The ratio 1:4 means one to four, hence we can represent it as " 1:4."<n><n>### Instructions:Please identify correct or wrong answers below.<n><n>### Example:(a) The ratio  4:7 can be written like this 4:7.<n><n>(b)*(c) 7/14 is a fraction.<n><n>### The Question:<n><n>Which of the following statements are true, based on the following equation?<n><n>(2 + 5)/(5 + 2)<n><n>### Part A<n><n>### Part B<n><n>### Part C<n><n>### Part D<n><n>### Instructed Response:<n><n>### Example<n><n>### Part E<n><n>### Part F:<n><n>### The question<n><n>### Answers:<n><n><n>

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The woman experienced great joy, but despite that this was a what? Choices:  A: misery B: sadness C: bad time D: sorrow E: play time<n><n>### Response:		The woman experienced great joy, yet her misery was only just beginning to fade after her bad time on play time.<n><n>### Explanation: <n>Misery refers to distress, trouble, sadness, wretchedness, etc. The phrase “her misery was only just begining to fade after her bad” refers to a gradual fading of wretchedness. A play time is a period of rest. We know that she experienced great joy, but she was experiencing a bad time (since she was experiencing distress while experiencing other things as well like rest).

Please do.<n><n>### 4) If you forget someone and they are right, let them know.<n><n>### If you forget someone and that person answers correctly, let them know. They will remember and it will have a positive impact on them.<n><n>### Write the option you chose and the reasons why.<n><n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The people wanted to take the scenic route, they chose the highway that cut through the what? It means "I am going". So it is going to happen.

Input: How many points are shown in an answer for which the correct answer is correct? (There are an infinite number of correct answers)<n>A. 0 points<n>B. 1 point<n>C. 2 points<n>D. 10 points<n>E. 20 points<n><n>### Response to question:<n><n>[36-Hour Rule](https://driving-tests.co.uk/theory-test/6-hour-rule/136-hour-rule.html)<n><n>In a multiple-choice question, there are 5 questions with each question having 4 answers. How many questions should you expect to find with at least one correct answer?<n><n>[55248632]<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>[4]<n><n>### Institutional Question:<n>There are three main elements of a written instruction.<n><n>### Answer to instruction:<n>C. If you think it’s too hard, go ahead, think about it, we’ll be there.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>Q. When writing instructions, which of these instructions might be helpful?<n>A. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Choices:  A: cross street B: milk cow C: lose weight D: step forward E: need food<n><n>### Response:		C.<n><n>### Justify:<n>In this question, we are told that Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda, Mara has twice as much as Janet and Mara has 4 times more than Janet, in total they have 211 cards.<n><n>To complete this question, we first count the total number of cards. To do this, we get the total amount of cards by adding the number of cards each person has. We now know there are 211 cards in all. We then multiply each number of cards each person, Janet=9, Brenda = 4 and Mara =211 by the total amount of cards to know the total number of cards each person got by each person.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? Choices:  A: get to know B: gain knowledge C: intelligence D: education E: gaining knowledge<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input<n>The total price of a dozen of eggs and a dozen of pears is $26.25. The eggs cost $2.00 more than the pears. How many eggs were purchased if the pears cost $0.50 less than a dozen?<n><n>### Response<n>Eight pears and a dozen eggs were purchased.<n><n>### Note: In math, what is the sum of the digits of 1?<n><n>###Response:1  <n><n>

Choices:  A: move away from B: laying in C: sweating D: movement E: walking out of<n><n>### Response:		A person can stop standing in a puddle by moving away from the puddle.<n><n>### Input <n>#### Choices:A: move away from B C: sweating D E: walking out of <n><n>### Response<n>A person can stop standing on a puddle. <n><n>If the water stays in the place under the person's feet, then the person has a chance to be standing on the puddle forever. Otherwise, moving feet means moving the whole person is off the surface of what the person was standing on.<n><n><n>### Input<n>#### <n><n>#### <n><n>### Output<n>#### A: move away from  C: sweating  D: walking out of  E:<n>A person can stop falling by moving away from the place the person was standing. Also, a person can become less likely to be standing on a pudge by moving their feet a bit.<n><n>The person can also prevent falling to being standing on a pudgle by moving their feet. If the person makes their feet move a bit and puts it on a solid surface, the entire body will move to the new surface.<n><n>#### A: move a way from B: sweating C: walking out of<n>A person can stop to falling by moving away from where they were standing if they are standing on a pudle.<n><n>The person will not sink the whole body in the puddle, but they will put the feet of the person in a better position. This will prevent the person from falling into a puddle and getting wet. <n><n>In case a person is standing on a pudding, they can prevent themselves from falling down by moving away from the surface. Moving the feet and placing them better will also prevent the person from sinking in the puddles.<n><n>

Choices:  A: go shopping B: generous C: earn money D: have money E: gift buyer<n><n>### Response:		<n>In this task, there are two options.<n>The first approach would be to use 1st option.<n>```<n>A: go shopping<n>```<n><n>This approach will use the first option which is 'go shopping'.<n>Since, "go shopping", has two words, we will add the first word's meaning and the second word's meaning in the list.<n><n>```<n>"go" or to travel <n>"shopping" or to search for items<n>```<n><n>Thus, since we have the word in the list already, we will write the whole phrase and not the phrases. (if we were using the 1st option)<n>So we have only one option left.<n><n>Second approach<n>```<n>In this approach, each option will be written down separately and not together.<n>We will start by creating a dictionary.<n>So, all of the options are written below.<n>```<n><n>```<n>A: shopping<n>```<n>A meaning: to travel <n>So, for this option, the first word has a meaning of traveling so we will write "to travel"<n>The second option is `go shopping` and the meaning of this option would be to search for item so we will write "search for item" in this one<n>So finally our dictionary for option A will be:<n>```<n>{"to travel":true,"search for item":true}<n>```<n>With that said and done, we will do the same thing for option B.<n>```<n>B: generous<n>```<n>So for this option, since generous means giving items, we will write the meaning of giving item which is "give items"<n>```<n>{'give items":true}<n>```

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What place would a person go to look at zebras? Choices:  A: zoo B: museum C: hospital D: desk E: opera<n><n>### Response:		(write the correct answer with justification. Use all the information to write a sentence. It does NOT have to be one big sentence. You can show multiple steps in a math problem)<n><n>[What place would a person](https://www.brainyquote.com/authors/samuel_johnson?page=2) ( ) look at zebras ( ) (<n><n>### Input :In a classroom, there is a pencil, a pen, and an eraser. The pencil and the eraser are equal, which means they equal each other. The pencil is less than twice the pen. Write 3.2 to 3.6 to show what fraction of the pencil and pen is equal to the eraser.<n><n>### Response :<n>[The pencil and the pen are not equal](https://www.youtube.com/results?q=the+giver+book+review). So how can they be equal to the eraser, who is also not equal to any of them? The eraser is less than twice the pencil so it makes more sense if they weren't equal. <n><n>### Input :(16 ÷ 4) x 2 Write an algebraic expression that shows the answer to the division when you use multiplication.)<n><n>### Response :(16 ÷ (4 ÷ 2 )) x 2) Showing work:  16 ÷ (8 ÷ 2 )): the expression is (32 ÷ 10) when you multiply. <n><n>## Input:A person is riding on his bicycle and passes a stop sign. After 3rd he turns right and passes 3rd again.  A mile later, the person stops at a cross walk and walks for 108 steps to get to his destination. How many feet did someone walk to their destination?<n><n>### Response:(3rd x 3) + (1 mile x 5280 feet/mile) + (108 steps /10,000 steps/mile) + (5280 feet) = 52,800 feet.<n><n>## Input:How many more days are there in a June than there are in a July?<n><n>###Response:(10/14*30) - (6/1

Choices: Crayons A: the kitchen B: crayon factory C: the bathroom D: crayons display E: garbage<n><n>### Response : Choice A the kitchen. The kitchen is the only place where I found Crayons.<n><n>### Explanation: Answer.<n><n>### A.   I found the crayons in the kitchen, since they are used to paint drawings in the kitchen.<n>### B.   I found the Crayola Factory in a small town just half an hour from where I live.<n>### C.   I found the bathroom, just like before in 2nd grade, but this time I used a different brand.<n>### D.   I found the display crayons in a book in the library which I read last year.<n>### E.   I found a lot of crayons in trash, but they weren't Crayola crayons.<n><n>

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:A person would carry a large netted drawstring bag to what sort of place? Choices:  A: humidifier B: surface of earth C: skating rink D: ice cube E: burn it to the ground<n><n>### Response:		Surface of Earth should be selected as the most feasible and effective answer option. The reason to choose surface of earth is that it is the most effective and feasible instrument that can be used to replenish the liquid in the atmosphere.<n><n>### Justification:<n><n>#### Experimental Evidence<n><n>The surface of earth absorbs liquids more efficiently than any other natural or artificial instruments.<n><n>#### Scientific Analysis<n><n>The surface of the earth is a strong and highly efficient tool for extracting moisture from the earth's atmosphere. <n><n>#### Theoretical Background<n><n>One can't find anything else more efficient and effective than the surface of the earth. <n><n>### Input:"I can only get one of these two choices, so you should stop wasting my time." The reason that I choose option "C" is because it is good for both options and, it is not good for only one option, neither it is poor.

Every day, he takes a different route. If he walks 9 miles a week taking all possible routes, how many miles does he take each day on average?<n><n>### Solution:<n>Due to the fact that Dexter walks 9 miles in all, we can assume that each day he takes the equivalent of 3 miles.<n>1. Using the "modulo" operator gives us 1 of 3 possibilities.<n>2. Multiply or subtract to get any choice.<n>3. The remainder of a division by 2 (floor(n/2)) with n being the week's total.<n>### Demonstion:<n>Input: Brenna has 6 cups of apple juice more than John. How much apple juice does Brenna have in total if John has 3 cups of lemonade?<n>Answer: 4 more<n><n>### Solution<n><n>1. Input: Brenna has x cups of apple juicw more than John<n>2. Calculate:  x+3<n>3. Get answer: 4<n>### Instruction<n>1. Give the output for the following statements. (Enter "0" if there is no output) 1. x-10<n>2. Give an example for the following expression. (Enter "0", if there is no example) 3*1//3<n>3. Write a statement about the following logical operators. (Enter “-” for negative) 4>1<n><n>### Demostration<n>1. x-1 < y-2 -> -<n>2. y < x -> 0<n>3.  z>5 -> 0<n>4. x < y -> 0<n>5.  y>x -> 1<n>6. x>y -> false<n>7. y>x -> true<n>8. y=x -> -<n>9. y<x -> 0<n>

Choices:  A: celebrate B: have party C: hear crowd go mad D: create success E: reproduce<n><n>### Response:		<n>This question is tricky because what constitutes a success when attempting to procreate can be subjective to the person asking the question. It might be the answer to question A (celebrate) above. For some, a party or hearing a crowd go wild might be considered a success. However, for others, that might not be considered a success.<n><n>### Input : On Monday, it rained. In the morning on Tuesday, it rained. Not on Thursday, it thundered. What day of the week was it on Friday?<n><n>### Response :Thursday<n><n>### Input<n>You can find out whether a set is a subset of another set by using the intersection operator. Suppose a set has values 1, 2, 3, and 4. A subset of this set is a set that has values 1 or 2. True or false? How do you determine whether a set is a proper subset of another set?<n><n>###Response:<n>For this question, the intersection operator returns a set of the intersection of the inputs of the operator. The intersection is the set that includes all the elements that are in both sets, in this case set A and set B. The intersection operator will return the intersection for set A and set B of 1 and 2 only. If the set that is returned after the intersection is empty or null, then the intersection is false. The intersection can also be seen as the elements that are in sets A and B but not in either of the sets by themselves. If this was the case, then the intersection is true.<n><n>###Input:  What is the smallest even prime number?<n><n>###Respone:<n>The smallest even prime number is 2<n><n>###Input<n>You can find out if a number is a prime number by using the isPrime operator. Suppose you want to check if 8 is a prime number. If it is, what does the isPrime method return?<n><n>###Repsonse<n>True or false? What would you expect the isPrime function to do if the input is false? How do you find whether a number is a prime or composite?<n><n>###Input1: 9/8<n><n>###Response1: 1.0875<n><n>###Input2: 14/7<n><n>###Response2: 2<n><n>##

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane?
