If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		<n>If input = "Choices:  A:  B:  C:  D:  E: ". I will go for answer = A and if input = "Choices not all of choices have been filled. Choose an answer". I'll go for answer = D and If I come across input = "Choose anwer. A, B, C, D are not all of choices". I'll go with any other option available.<n><n>If input = "Where do you put your graps just before checking out?". This mean, my task is to find where grapes are kept after checking. My goal is to check in this task, that which input do I choose and what response I should give.<n><n>### Input(2):There's no space between two objects. They either touch each other or there are no objects between them.<n><n>### Response(2):<n><n>If input = "\u2592:  There's no space between to objects. They either touch other or there's nothing between them.". This means, the two objects are either touched or there is nothing between them. If I come across input with the same meaning, I must give response = "B". If input = " \u2592B: is no space between two objects". The task mean, there is no space b/w two objects and response = "C". If input = "\u2392D: is between two object". Responsue = "D". If I get input = "\u26A2C: there is no space between two object". My response must be = "C".

What percentage of the people at the party live in the country?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>First solve for the number not married: 53<n><n>53 -13 = 40<n><n>Percentage = 40\<n>/ 60 = 0.666666...<n><n>### Input A store can display items in either of two places, the "east wall" and the "west wall". Of 40 shirts, 20 would fit on the east wall and 10 would fit on the west wall, leaving 6 shirts to be displayed elsewhere. Given these data, what is the probability of a randomly chosen shirt would be displayed west?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>60% Probability of west wall = 40/60 = 2/3 <n><n>### Input : A pizzeria in Chicago has 100 employees.<n>50 are male<n>50 are female<n>How many employees does the pizza place employ in all?<n><n>### Demo :<n>50*100 = 5,000<n><n>5000 + 5000 = 10,000<n>### Instruction : Answer the question based on the graph provided.<n><n>### Input - Data<n><n>![image](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Hassan-Asheikin/Prep_work/main/Teaching_material/Past_Test/2022%2012%2015.png)<n><n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Demo<n><n>![image](http://imgur.com/6bWm9x6.png)<n><n>### Data :<n><n>How many items total are displayed in the store?<n><n>### A : 5650<n><n>How many items are displayed in the east wall?<n><n>### B : 4012<n><n>### Data A and Data B<n><n>### Output<n><n>The probability of a random item being displayed on the east wall

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:You can share files with someone if you have a connection to a what? Choices:  A: freeway B: radio C: wires D: computer network E: electrical circuit<n><n>### Response:		You can share files with someone via a computer network. By clicking on a button labeled "share", the sharing of the file will be initiated.<n><n>### Input :<n>**Ethan is taking 2 classes this year! For his 11th grade level algebra class,<n>he has about 3 times as many assignments as his English 10 class.<n>However, each assignment in his English class takes twice as long as the math assignment.<n>How much longer does Ethan spend doing math than English?**<n>**(5x3-4x2)/3 = 5/4 -> 1.25hrs or 20 minutes**<n><n><n><n>The next task is to complete the instruction that describes a task in your own words. Write a response that contains at least 3 complete sentences.<n>### Input: The teacher wants to share a video with the class. They need to make sure every student has downloaded the link. She sends the link to Mr. and Mrs. Jones but she forgets Mr. and Mrs. Smith. There are 18 students in the class and if everyone has successfully downloaded the video, how many students does the teacher need to send an email to?<n>### Response:<n>The teacher has 18 students and needs to send an email to each and every student if every student has sucessfully downloaded the video and Mr. and Mrs. JOnes also have downloaded the video. The teacher needs to send 19 emails or 1 more email than all the students in the class. The teacher needs to find 19 emails to send to Mr. Jones, Mrs. Jones, and 18 student emails.<n><n>### Submission: When you are finished, submit the file named "Day_3_Task_2" on the challenge canvas.

The text prompts are provided only as a guide, for each question it should be easy for you to come up with your own unique text prompt.<n><n>* If I were to add 34 and 16, I would get...(add the numbers and give the answer) __________<n>* I took a survey of how many people would rather eat cheese pizza than pepperoni. 53% of the students said they prefer to eat pepperoni pizza.  __________ percent of the students prefer pepperoni to cheese.<n>* In a school with (50) 10 to 12 year or older students, how many years old are they in total?  __________<n>* If you start off with (5) 1/3 cup containers of water, what is (9) divided by 5? __________<n>* Each week, a family of people buy (5) dozen eggs, (4) pounds of rice, (4) cups of tomato sauce, and (3) cups of coffee. The family has (9) cents more than they did last week. How much money do they have to spend this week? __________<n><n>### Answer<n>##### Examples<n>* If I were the president, I would be the leader of the government.<n>* The answer to 34 + 16 is 50<n>* 53 percent of the students prefer cheese pizza<n>* 266 students are<n>* 19<n>* 64 cents

Choices: A: paintingB: hen houseC: californiaD: VirginiaE: movie hall<n>Correct answer is option D (Virginia)<n><n><n><n><n>### Lesson 19 Answer<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The fox is somewhere far from where painting takes place, so that does not make the fox painted at all.<n><n>### The hen house may contain chicken's eggs in abundance, but it does not contain water directly. <n><n>### California is a state that has water, but it is too far for a fox to cross. <n><n>## Expected response

Your function should have the following code signature: `print_distinct_numbers_from (a, b)`.  Your function should return nothing.<n><n>Write a function called `print_distinct(a)` that takes in an array of numbers, and displays the distinct numbers found in that array.<n><n>To achieve this, you will have to create 4 functions: `distinct_number`, `not_distinct_number`, and then `print_distinct` to do so.<n><n>Your `distinct_number` function simply returns `true` for a number that is found in the array, and `false` for a number that does not appear in the array.<n><n>Your `not_distinct` function simply returns `false` for the first parameter if it is equal to the second parameter, otherwise, it returns `true`.<n><n>Your `print_distinct ` function simply uses `a` as a parameter, and uses array slicing to display the distinct numbers in the array.<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The city's community garden was demolished for yet another what? Choices:  A: wasteland B: ocean C: desert D: parking lot E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer:  B<n><n>### Input - In a community garden, there are 6 sunflowers that are twice as tall as the other sunflowers and 5 beans plants. Each plant has a different number of beans. The beans plants have 38 rows of beans. How many rows of beans does the tallest sunflower have?<n><n>### Response - 55 - because the tallest sunflowers have 58 rows<n><n>### Input<n><n>The sunflowers in the community garden have 61, 58, and 57 rows of beans. Their beans are twice as big as the rest. The tallest sunflower has 28 rows that have a bigger number of sunflower beans.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Sunflower beans have twice the number of beans as other sunflowers. There are 6 sunflower beans in each sunflower row. 6 * (2 * 38) = 204<n><n>### Input 1<n><n>The garden has sunflowers and beans. It has 38 rows of sunflowers that have 58 beans each. The rows of beans have 6, 7, 17, and 17 each. 52 flowers have 64 beans each, and flowers have 56 and 60 beans each. How many beans are there in the garden?<n><n>### Respons<n><n>718 is the number of beans.<n><n>---<n><n>## 130 Questions for SIS:<n>

The word sadness describes one's disposition and the word sad characterizes a mood. A gloomy mood or disposition is sad.

The term "animal" is the classification for multiple organisms that are members of kingdom protista, animalia, or plantae. In addition, Chickens are included in class mammalia which is part of kingdom animalia. Other examples of animals are deer, dogs, beavers, bees, frogs, and eagles.<n><n>### Next Question:In 2 hours and 28 minutes, does it need more than 1 hour?<n><n>### Instructions: If true, enter true. But if you are on a bridge, throw the rock into a river on the bridge. <n><n>### Input:(8)(3)(3)(3)(7)(1)(7)(7)(7)<n><n>### Response:(0)<n><n>### Input<n>Jerry goes to the supermarket twice in one day. On the first visit, he buys two boxes of milk, two cans of rice, two eggs, and one package of beef. What is the missing number?<n>13<n><n>##Input:Two students were on vacation for two days and spent 60 coins in one day and 55 coins in the other. The sum of all the coins the students spent is 92. If the two days are two weeks apart, find the distance traveled for each day.<n>2<n><n>##Answer:One day is equal to a week<n>```python<n>if(n % (2 ** 10) == 0):<n>    return n//(2 ** 10);<n>```<n><n>##InputAfter 2 days, the total number of co

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Where are people likely to find food? Since Annie new net change with the rebates it comes out too $255.00<n>### Instrucion:Analyze the situation and make a decision.<n><n>### Question:A teacher asked Sam to put a book back onto the shelf. If I work without the calculator I have time too it takes me to get it right. This is only because when you work with the calculator all you have is the time that you have been given and your answer so the next time you have to answer in the same way.<n><n>### Feel free to provide any comments on general learning in our class session that you feel are important.<n><n>* General Comments<n>	* I think this class was easy for me to learn. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What is the hope of playing sports without competition? Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		B<n>### Input:Fill in the blank:The number is one more than the number I subtract.<n><n>### Response:{<n>### Input:How many fewer balls will I have after subtracting one ball from the ball? Choices: <n>#### 1: fewer B<n>#### 2: one fewer C<n>#### 3: the same D<n>#### 4: twice as many<n><n>### Response:#4<n><n>### Input:#5<n><n>### Response:/home/student/git/repos/programming-java/src/solutions<n><n>### Input:"Most" in this problem means:<n><n>### Response:"Most in all"<n>### Input:The number of candles is equal to the number of times I've counted.<n>### Response:The candles are evenly distributed<n><n>### Input/home/java:<n>### Input:-=<n>### Response:-=<n>### Input:I had more balls when I was 4 than when I was 3. How many more?<n><n>### Input:{<n>### Input:{*3<n>### Response:{*3<n>## Input:I have just as many apples to peel than apple slices.<n>## Response:<n><n>##Input:The number of pears is more than twice the number of apples and pears combined.<n><n>##Response:<n><n>##Input:"I had 3 more pear slices than apple slices when all slices totaled 44"<n><n>##Responese::  I had a total of 44 slices when I had 21 more pear slices!<n><n>##Input:"My slices had "<n>##Responese:My slices had a total of 32!<n><n>##input"The number of slices is more than 2 times the number of pears sliced. What does the underlined clause clarify about the sentence?<n><n><n><n>* The walk through the countriside was far-reaching.<n>* Althea saw many trees<n>* Althea was walking through the country.<n>* The trees in the country were nesting in the woods.<n>* Birds nest.​<n><n><n>### Insturction: Answer the following true/false statement.<n><n>* I live in a house with 48 rooms. (True)<n>* I like to play basketball with my friends. (True)<n><n>### Instrutction: Read the sentence below: A man built a brick path around his house with a walkway on one side and a garden on the other. The underlined part of the sentence does what for this sentence?<n><n><blockquote>A man built a brick path…with a garden on the other.</blockquote><n> <n><n>* A path runs around a house.<n>* A brick house has a path around it with a garden on one side and a walkway on the other.<n>* A walkway is built along the path of a walk.<n>* A path is in front of a brick house.<n>* The man built a brick path with a walkway on each side.<n><n>### Istrution: Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>1. True or False: Sara has 4 dogs and 7 chickens.<n><n>### Response<n>2. If the total number of birds and cats is equal to the total number of chickens and cats, how many chickens and cows are in the picture?<n>      <n>3. Which word in the sentence is an example of an adverb?<n><n>**Examples**: <n><n>A bird, on the other hand, does well by using its beak to break food.<n>A farmer used an adjective phrase to describe a farm.<n>A bird eats a variety of food.<n>A word that describes where something happened has an adverbial phrase in it.

On Tuesday, Alissa earns 6 more than 2 times her salary. What is Alissa's salary on Monday?<n>### A<n><n>### Instrumental Variable<n><n>### Instructed Question:How can we solve a system of two equations in two unknowns?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Equations:<n><n>$6 x + 2y = 6$<n>$2 y + 3x = -1$<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### System of Equations:<n>$6 x +2y = 6, 2y+3x = -1\implies \frac{6x+2y}{-1} = 1$<n><n>##|:  |2/3 x - 1/5 y = -2, 4/5 y = -10/5 |<n>##|  :  |4 x - 3 y = 9, 4 y = 9 |<n>##|:     |2/3 x + 1/5 y + 3/10 x = 1/10 y, \frac{3}{10} y = 2 |<n>##|     |2 x + 3 y + 2/10 x = y, -2 y = 20/100 |<n><n>### Installed Question<n><n>### Insturctions:How can we combine the equations: $u(t) = 50 - kt^2$ and $v(t) = -k t$?<n><n>### Demo<n><n>### Question:A car is moving at 997km/hr. Choices:  A: bookstore B: house C: race track D: friend's house E: building<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>    #include <iostream><n>    using namespace std;<n><n>    const int MAXSIZE = 1001;<n><n>    int find(int n[],int x,int y)<n>    {<n>        int sum=0, i=0;<n>         while(i<y)<n>         sum=(sum+n[i++])%MAXSIZE;<n>        if(sum==x)<n>        {<n>            cout<<"found";<n><n>            return 0;<n>        }<n><n>        return 1;<n>    }<n><n>    int main()<n>    {<n>        cout << "\t\t\t\n\n\n\t\t\t  The Dollar Birds.\n\n\n" ;<n>        int n[MAXSIZE] = {};<n>        int x = 0, y = 1; //x:position to search y:value to search<n>        while(1==1)<n>        {<n><n>            int choose=find(n,x,y);<n><n>            if(choose)<n>            break;<n><n>            x++;<n>            if(x==n[0])<n>            y++;<n><n>        }<n>    }<n>

If number greater than 20,000, write "tera in the sentence.<n><n>Input: The number 999<n>Output:"The Number 999 is 1,001,287."<n><n>Input: Do input from the user. <n>Output: "The Number 99,999 is 7,9248,163."<n><n>Input:  Do input from the user<n>Output: The number 894 is 5,141.<n><n>Input:  A: 4,000<n>Output: The number A is 51,200. A is MEGA.<n>Input:  B: 9,580<n>Output: The Number B is 1.359. B is <n>mega.<n>Input:  C: 2,325<n>Output: The Number C is 165. C is giga.<n>Input:  D: 14,312<n>Output: The Number D is 9,192. D is mega.<n>Input: Do input form the user again.<n>Output: The Number E is 7,777. E is not a palindrome.<n><n>### Solution <n><n>### Input<n><n>Here are examples of input.<n><n>```<n>30<n>8.004532<n>```<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Here are examples.<n><n>```<n>The number 30 is 401.<n>The number 8.004325 is 8.00,04325.<n>```<n><n>## Solving<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Illinois does not have any apple trees in it.<n><n>### Input:(25-5 ÷5) -8<n><n>### Response:(25-5)÷5<n>### Explanatioon:(25-5)=175×5=875<n><n>### Input : 123 +123.0 <n>### Input:123.422.4<n>### Response: 123.4<n>### Explanatorion:3.422-4=-1.422 which has a decimal in a negative place which is 1.422-1.422=0.0<n><n>### A group of 48 students are split into three equal groups and are asked to memorize a set of flashcards<n>### Question: How many flashcards do they need as a group?<n>### Answer: 96<n>### Explanatoin: 48 divided by 3 the result is 16 which is an even number therefore the result is 2. Which makes 16 × 2 = 32, 32 times 2 is 64 which is a multiple of 16. <n>In this case we have 64 × 2 which gives us 128. The answer is 128. <n><n>### If there are 205 students in a school, and the ratio of boys to girls is 5:8, how many boys are there?<n>### Answer=105<n>### Explaniation: (300 /10):10 = 30, 190 boys.<n>### If Janine had 3 pounds worth of apples; what was the cost equivalent per pound of her apples on her recent backpacking trip?<n>### Answer=$5.21<n>### Explanaton:<n>### Cost=30 $<n>### Cost of 1 pound=$1.66167<n>### Therefore<n>### per weight:$1.661 +3=499<n>### A small cake store has 18 bags of cake batter, each with 3 dozen cupc

Write a program to get the average of three number <n><n>## Question:<n>What is the role of a programmer?<n>```<n>The responsibility is to understand the business as best as they can, work closely with stakeholders in order to deliver the business value as quickly as possible to meet and exceed every expectation, the user. This means they need to understand the user from everyday life, the users who are the customers, and the users who are the staff and ensure that everything delivered helps both sides.<n>The primary role of a programmer is to develop and support software applications. However, many programmers assume other titles, as well, according to the businesses and organizations for which they work, including computer and information system manager and web developer.<n>```<n><n>## Response 1<n>```bash<n>What is the role a programmer?<n><n>This is a question which only developers/programers can answer!<n>I can only give you my personal experience and this is what I do!<n>```<n>```bash<n>You can work as a developer/programer! A lot of programers out there,<n>it helps to know how to code, but also having knowledge about technology and IT,<n>I would say is a must!<n>But the most important thing is to never stop learning,<n>stay up-to-date with the new tech<n>and always find a way to develop your self<n><n>My main job as a programer is to develop and support a software (app/application)<n>If I write good and clean code, then it makes my job easier as it reduces the bug fix rate and the need to redo work. Therefore, I always try to write good code in a clear way and make the code easy to understand when I review it. Apart from writing and supporting software, we also work as team players and always try to take part in team activities that make us more effective in what we do.<n>```<n><n><n><n><n>## Question: <n>How do you become a programming expert?<n>```

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What are ai machines known for doing? Choices:  A: fly B: milk cows C: eat D: answering questions E: fail to work<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>B<n><n>### Input :You have seen AI used to do a task successfully.Which of these is not another example of AI that was successful?<n><n>### Response :<n><n>A) Tiger Woods <n><n>### Input<n><n>How many minutes does the average driver spend stuck in traffic?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer : 7.7 minutes<n><n>### Input AI is:<n><n>### Response A:<n><n>a computer<n><n>### Response B:<n><n>an autonomous agent<n><n>### Response C:<n><n>a self learning machine<n><n>### Input What is a major limitation of AI?<n><n>### response A:<n><n>they are slow<n><n>### responseB:<n><n>They don’t have a very good memory<n><n>### responseC:<n><n>they are only effective for large data sets<n><n>### Input Given some numbers and rules, a machine can find the answer to some difficult tasks. Which of the following can this machine not do? <n><n>###Response A:<n><n>tell jokes<n><n>###Response B:<n><n>add long numbers<n><n>###Response C:<n><n>perform complex calculations <n>

Choices:  A: deceptive B: altruistic C: stupid D: cruel E: agressive<n><n>### Response:		<n>***D.***<n>In a study about how good you are at solving problems, there was a test, 24 subjects passed the test.<n>I have made a chart and I am going to graph the data.<n><n>Here is the graph i made below.<n><n>|                          |Pass |Fail |<n>| :------------------------| ----: | ---: |<n>| 1st to 5th                 | 12   |   3 |<n>| 6th to 10th               |   3  |   7 |<n>| 11th to 15th              |    1 |  11 |<n>| 16th to 24th              |    4 |  24 |<n>| 25th to 30th              |   10 |  12 |<n>| 31st to 36th              |    3 |   6 |<n>| 37th to 42nd              |    2 |   6 |<n><n>### Response Data:<n><n>| **Category** | **Explanation** |<n>| :---------- | :----------------- |<n>| 1. How many points did Jordan get on that practice test? | 43. She answered __of them__ correctly. |<n>| 2. If the test is 55 questions, how many questions did _____ answer correctly? | 23. She answered __percent__ of the questions correctly. |<n>| __Answer the rest of the questions at the very end and skip any that don't apply.__|<n><n>### Input :<n>When I look at this question it reminds me of my cousin ____ they never seem to do well on tests because if they do well on a test it's because they cheated. |<n><n>### Instructions: You're going to be using the word 'is' or 'are' in your short response. Do not make major changes to the wording. You'll be given a few options of text and you will respond to them using these terms. 1. I like to think I'm smart but maybe that's not correct. 2. He did badly in school and it affected _____. 3. I've noticed that ______ more. 4. She's not a particularly good actress but she's managed to land several large roles. 5

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. Choices:  A: being understood B: beer C: playing around D: hug E: visiting friends<n><n>### Response:		How many friends have come back that you had overseas last summer?<n><n>### Input Choices:A: 0 B: 1 C: 10 D: 20 E: 50<n>Answer: A<n><n>### InputChoices:A: No B: 0 C: 7 D: 14 E: 21<n>Answer: C<n><n>### InputChoice:A: More money than his dad B: No money at all C: Fewer chores than his brother D: Some money E: Never goes to the store without asking for money<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input:(1-5): Choose one<n><n>### Response:(1-5): Do not provide all the numbers. Just a range is enough.<n><n>### Answer: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5<n><n>### Inputs: If a family does not go to a movie until they have 40, then they have:<n><n>### Response Choices:A: No choice B: More money since they can pay more to go to the movie theatre often C: Fewer money, they have to save up more to go to the movies often D: They like going to movies E: More food to eat at home, they can save more going to the movie theatre<n><n>### Answer:(1-5): B<n><n>### Example Input: 7.<n>### A B<n>8.<n>9.<n><n>### Example Response: Choice B<n><n>9.<n><n>9.<n>9.<n>9 <n>9<n><n>9.<n>> **Sample Solution**<n><n>{% include math/latex.html title="Solution to Example Instruction" content="<div class=\"instruction-example\">\n  <input type=\"text\" />\n  <input class=\"answer-input\" type=\"radio\" /> <label class=\"answer-label\" for=\"choice-1\">A\</label>\n  <input class="answer-input" type=\"radio\" /><label class=\"answer-answer-label\" for="choice-2">B\</label>\n   <input class=\"answer\" type=\"checkbox\" /><label class="answer-answer" for="choice-3">C\</label>\n    <input class=\"answer\"/><label class

Choices:  A: living B: feeling good C: hyperventilate D: look around E: breathe deeply<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Task:<n>Write a program using the instruction provided below to show your answer.<n><n>### Input/Instruction:<n><n>| 1 | How many times does “G” appear the largest?         |<n>| - | - |<n>| 1 |<n>| [A]         |<n>| 11         |<n><n>| 2 | How many places does “J” come second in the list?         |<n>| 2 | - |<n>| [B]         |<n>| [C, D]         |<n>| D         |<n>| [A, C]         |<n>| B         |<n><n>| B | There are 8 digits in the numbers.         |<n>| -  | 1 |<n><n>## Task: Write a program using the instruction that described a task below which uses 7 strings.<n>### Instruction/Input: Write a line for each string:<n><n>The first string is “hello world”. The second string is “hello how are you?”. The third string is “is that a hello to me?”. The fourth string is “yes yes I’m well.” The fifth string is “what about you?”. The sixth string is “no not I.” The seventh string is “good to know I’m afraid.”<n>The first string is the longest. The second string is the second longest. The third string is the third longest. The fourth string is the fourth longest. The fifth string is the fifth longest. The sixth string is the sixth longest. The seventh string is the seventh longest. 1, the first is 8, the second is 7, the third is 6, the fourth is 5, the fifth is 4, the sixth is 3, the seventh is 2.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>| 0 | The letters "hello" appear once.         |<n>| 0 | - |<n><n>| 11 | "world" appears once between "hello" and "I'm."         |<n>| 6 | - |<n><n>The numbers are: "1", "2", "3", "4", "5", "6", "7".<n>| 21 | The first and second strings are the same length.         |<n>| [B, A]         |<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:The other passengers on the bus were quite loud, so he put on his headphones to relax and what? Choices:  A: go to bed B: sleep C: listen to music D: stretch out E: stop worrying<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n><n>In a classroom, there were 7 children assigned to work together on a science project. They had a long discussion about how to tackle their science concept and ended up with this plan.<n><n>Each morning they took a long walk to a field nearby and spent 45 minutes observing the plants and weather before returning and recording their observations. After that, they spent another hour in the classroom collecting and analyzing information they found on their topic using books, the internet, and videos. They wanted to present their findings in a 4 slide PowerPoint, so the next day they spent 30 minutes designing their slides and practicing them until they were smooth! Finally, they presented their presentation to the class. A total of 2.5 hours were spent on science the day before the next day's field trip.<n><n>### Response<n><n>The classroom used was used for 385 minutes during each school day. There is 60 minutes in an hour. If 385 is more than 9, subtract 9 from 385.<n>The answer is 376.

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:In the movie a fragile man is causing accidents, his hope is to find a person opposite of him who is what? Choices:  A: undestroyable B: unbreakable C: indestructible D: durable E: invisible<n><n>### Response:		(a) A or B, (b) E<n><n><n>### Inputs<n>Janet has 7 pencils more than Brenda. Mary has twice as many pencils as Janet. How man pencils do they have in all?<n><n><n>Answer: The numbers of pencils they have should be answered as follows:<n><n>* Janet has <n>    7+x<n>* Brenda has <n>    5+x<n>* Mary has <n>    8x<n>* So, their total number of pencils = 12+6x (the number of pencils Mary has)<n><n><n>##<n>

Choices:  A: movie B: cape kennedy C: space center D: military installation E: spaceship centre<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>Input:<n><n>In a classroom, there is 8 blue chairs and 10 red chairs. There are some children who sit with their friends at the tables.<n><n>Davina sits with her friends and they have 3 red chairs between them and it is Davina's own chair, it is 3/8 of her chairs. She has a chair, so she has more chairs than the other children.<n><n>Jemima sits with her friends who have 4 red chairs between them. The 4 red chairs that Jemima was at was 3/5 of her chairs, so she has more red chairs than the children that sat with them.<n><n>Ruqayya sits with her friends. Her chair is 4/8 of her chains. It was 1/3 of the chair there, so she has fewer chairs than 6 other children. She has an even number of red chairs there.<n><n>Jesse and Jesse's friends have 5 red chairs between them, if the chair she has is 1/8 of the chairs there, she has the same as 2 children.<n><n>Input: 2,8,6,4 and 3<n><n>What is the product?<n><n>Input: Jesse and Jesse' time at school and they all have a different number of friends that 5,4,3,2 and 1<n><n>What is their total number of friends?<n><n>Input: 1 and 4<n><n>1 ÷ 4 is 0.25<n>

Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		They were able to fix the old barn.<n><n>### Input - Find 4th coordinate pair by following the 2 steps<n><n>### Input :  -4  -2  -5  -1  -3  2  -8 ...<n><n>### Demostration: Step 1: Select every other number in the input sequence (in this case, select 2nd and 4th number -2 -5 )  Step 2:Select every 4th or 2nd number after the selection ( in this case -4 -8 )<n><n>### Demotstration: Step 1 : Select every other number in Inte (in this case,select 2nd and 5th number -2 -8 ) <n><n>Step 2 : Select every 3rd or 5th number after the selection (in this case -2 -4)<n><n>### Demosrtaion: Step 1 :Select every 6th number in the sequence (in this case -8) <n><n>Step 3: Select every 4th number after the selection by taking numbers from every 6th number (if a odd value is present, its position is divided by 4 and the remainder is removed ) (in this case)<n><n>Step 4: Select every 5th after the selection of the 4th one by taking number from every 4th number ( if an odd number is present, its position and remainder is divided by 3 and remainder is removed)<n><n>### The best way to use the method is by taking the values in the sequence as an integer and then selecting 4th, and lastly divide it by 5 which is the average number of steps which is not equal to 2<n><n><n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: shopping cart B: cashier C: shopping mall D: supermarket E: bookstore<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Explain:<n>The correct answer to the above question is a cashier, but it was given as a supermarket.<n><n>### Validate and explain:<n><n><n>### Input(s) and Output:<n>Input: There are four times as many girls on the basketball team as on the football team. On each team 1/5 of the members are starters. The number of girls on the basketball team is 70 less than the number of boys on the team. How many girls are on the soccer team?<n>Output: 145<n><n>### Validation:<n>Correct! This output is correct because 6 girls on the basketball team are starters. Then, there are 4 times as many girls on a team as are on a football team (4 * 6 = 24), and 70 girls are on the basketball team, leaving (24 - 70) = 5 * 1 = 5 remaining starter girls. Then, 5 of 8 = 5/8 = 62.5%. There are 8 girls on the football team, so 62.5% of them are starters. Therefore, there are 6 girls starters on the football team. Next, 6 * 1/5 = 32 is 32 girls starters on the basketball team. 70 - (5 * 1) - (32 * 1) = 4 * 6, which is twice as many girls as boys. 4 * 6 = two times, or 12 more than the starters on the basketball. 4 * 12 = 48. 70 - 48 = 22 girls are on the soccet team.<n><n>### What could be done to improve the validation?<n><n>I will consider the first step in the logic of the student: the student states that there are 4 times times as many girls on each team than each team; then, we can see what value is given for each team. (I will use * to represent the multiplication operator: * is shaped like the character *.) The first step is simply to write, Girls*Girls + Girls*Boys = Girls+Girls (or g * g + g * b = g + g). I could then solve the first term by subtracting

If Jan has 6 cars, how many cars does Bill have?<n><n><n>### Instructuin:<n><n><n>Input:Alan,Betty and Chris have different numbers of stamps. Alan has more stamps than Betty and Chris has the smallest number. Chris has 8 stamps fewer than half the number of stamps that Alan has. If Alan has 69 stamps, how many stamps does Betty have?<n><n><n><n>### Response<n><n>B:<n><n>Answer:Betty has 21<n><n>The number of stamps of Betty are greater than Chris that is 69. The number of Chris's stamps is half of the number of stamps of Alan that is 21. Half of 69 is 34.5. Subtract the number of Chris's Stamps from 34.5 you will get 69-34.5=34.5. Now, half of 34.5 is 17.25. Subtract that from 69 which is equal to 21. Therefore Betty has 21 stamps<n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n><n>Input:-Jane is 8 feet 6 inches taller than Paul.-Paul is taller than John and Bob but shorter than Henry. <n>He has 17 inches on Mary and Jane. If Mary is 6 ft 3 inches tall, how tall are Jane and Henry? <n>How tall is John?<n><n>### Responset<n><n>Jane:<n><n>Answer:9 feet 5 inches<n><n>Jane is 8 ft 6 inches taller from Paul who is 6 ft 7 inches high. Mary is 6 ft tall. 17 inches is 7.5 feet. Divide the 7.5 feet by 2 which is equal to 3.75 feet. Finally, add the 3.75 to 6 to get 9.75. Then, subtract 6 from 9.75 which is equal t o 9.35. Therefore, Jane is 9.35 ft tall<n><n>###

He can divide the money among his 9 pockets so that no pocket gets more than three times the total of the remaining pockets. How much money was in each of his pockets?<n><n>### Answer 16<n>### Input<n>If you start with a pile of 24 blue marbles and 12 green marbles, how many marbles do you have if you have a third as many green marbles as blue marbles?<n><n>### Input 16<n>##What is the rule?<n>Green marbles are triple blue marbles.<n><n>### Let's write this as an equation.<n>(3 green marbles) = 1 blue marbles<n><n>### That's good but let's be specific.<n>Let's create the rule.<n><n>### Green marbles = 3, blue marbles = 1<n>### Let' start the pile with 12 green marble and 24 blue marble.<n>### We'll count the blue marbles first. If we take away 1 blue marble, how many blue marbles will we have?<n>23 blue marbles<n>### How does it work with green marbles?<n>21 green marbles.<n>### How many overall?<n>24 + 21 = 45<n>### In code:<n>24+21=45<n>### Paste it here:<n>```text<n>24+27=45<n>```<n>### How many will there be with piles of marbles:<n>```text<n>3=40<n>```<n>### Paste the code and place here:<n>```text <n>blue marble 40, green marble (3)<n>```<n>### The equation will be:<n>```text<n>(3 green marble) = 1 blue<n>```<n>```text<n>3*3=27 (blue)<n>3*40=180 (blue marble)<n>```<n>##What is the blue marble rule for the equation?<n>```text<n>3 =

For the other options, replace y with - and it becomes y=2𝑥+(-2)-8=-8 and (x=- 3y)y=-2𝑦=-2𝑯 and x=1-3𝑥𝑦=-1𝑭 so they are off by 1 and not 2<n><n>### Input Write an algebraic expression which has the same value as (4x2 + 6x).<n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Bob needs a level to hang a shelf but cant find one in his home. Where would he go to get one? Choices:  A: glass of water B: build evenly C: garage D: carpenter's shop E: video game<n><n>### Response:		 D<n><n>### Instructions:In a recent 500 person survey, 65% of the individuals in the study were under 50 years old. How many individuals in the study were over 50 years old?<n><n>### Instrections<n>Answer with your own numbers<n>### Response 55%<n><n>### Instructins:<n>You have 10 pieces of toast, three pieces of toast in each slice. How do you cut it?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>You cannot cut a piece of toast, you cannot cut it equally if you have only one piece, and cut all pieces.<n><n>### Response<n>### Not in order answer<n>### Answer A: You cannot cut it in 10 pieces.<n>### Answer C: You cannot cut it, because you only have 10 toasts.

Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		<n>We know that humans take in oxygen through their lungs and diaphragm. The air through the open air that goes to the lungs to be breathed in is the main way we humans breathe.<n><n>###  Inference:<n>This means that the air that is going into peoples lungs has to go through the open air first before it reaches the lungs that needs to be breathed in. Without the air through the open air it would be very hard to breathe.<n>### Demontration<n>As I take a breath, and breathe in, there is two different areas in my stomach that moves as I breath. It is like I'm pumping my stomach as I breathe in. I can even do it with just one hand on my stomach. There is the lungs that take in the air and the diaphragm.<n><n>Diaphragm:  The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle that moves up and down between the stomach cavity and the chest cavity. The diaphragm contracts to expand the stomach cavities, thereby increasing the amount of air that can be taken in during breathing.<n><n>![](https://res.cloudinary.com/dgf3c30g/image/upload/q_auto,f_auto/v1535710664/diaphragm-1-lngwf6.png)<n><n>Lung:  The lungs are a pair of spongy, air-filled sacs in the chest cavity that extract oxygen from inhaled air, and expel carbon dioxide. The lungs also regulate blood pressure, control inflammation, and maintain fluid balance in the body.<n><n>![](http://diseases.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Diseases-of-the-Lung3.jpg)<n><n>There is a picture of my lungs and diaphragma. The diaphragma is a muscle.<n><n>### Inference:<n>There are two main parts of breathing, the lungs that take the fresh air, and the diaphragma that contracts to open the stomach. I have been breathing in the same way since I could

Mice are found in houses<n>4. Giraffe are found on savannahs.<n><n><n>### Output:<n>1. On a veldt.<n>2. In the ocean.<n>3. On a savannah.<n>4. Choices:  A: spinning wheel B: on a ladder C: hospital bed D: legroom E: grand piano<n><n>### Response:		<n><mark>B</mark><n><n>### Input(s): What is the largest continent on Earth?<n><n>### Response(s):<n><mark>A</mark><n><n>[https://www.brainbox.org/questions/24467.html](https://www.braindumpsite.net/exam/70-703/braindumps)<n><n>### Input<n><n>| How much is 2 ₵, 20₵, and 50₵? |<n>| --- |<n>| A: 84 |<n>| B: 35 |<n>| C: 13 |<n>| D: 7 |<n><n>### Options<n><n>* A<n>* B<n>* C<n><n>### D: E: A: D: E:<n><n>### Option: A: D: A: A: A:<n><n>**Explanation** <n><n>The options above use a list of 3 choices instead of a single option. It's more complicated, but it's more of a "what" question than a "how many" question, since you have both a list of things and an answer.<n><n>Also, you can use <mark>B</mark>, which removes the <sup>A</sup>, <sup>B</sup> line and replaces it with a list of options. However, you may not have this option with every question.<n><n>## Explanation<n><n>The first option for a multiple choice problem is always a "yes/no" choice with one line.  You simply put the answer on one line inside <sup>A</suppr 321, 118, 68</suppr>, and put your options on another line using <sup>B</suppr, C, D, E</suppr>.<n><n>After completing the first answer, you will have to repeat this process for the remaining options.<n><n>To show a complete statement, put the choice, which always uses a line, on one line. The options always come in the form of a simple question with one paragraph and no question mark.<n><n>The first option is always a yes/no question, where you must choose one of the three options that come after the yes/no.<n><n>After completing all the options, you go back to

A: one pencil at 25 cents B: four pencils at 50 cents C: ten pencils at 90 cents D: five erasers at 5 cents E: 60 papers at 25 cnets<n>### Response<n>E<n><n>## Description of Problem Solving<n><n>### Instructions<n>* Input: Janet has 4 times as many cards as Brenda. Janet has 1/2 the pencils and Janet has 3 times as many erasers as Brenda. All together they have 257 cards, 51 erasers, and 8 pencils. How many cards does Janet have if Brenda has 286 cards? How many do they have together?<n><n>### Process<n>* Brenda has 2 cards and Janet has 2 card and to get Janet's card they put 2 and 2 together and the answer is 4 and to get Janet and Brenda's card put 4+4=8 to gt a total of 2 cards and get Janet's total is 2+2=4<n>* Now to get Brenda's total they put 10 more cards to make it have 11 cards and 25 more paper to make it 36 cards and 26 more pencils to make it 57 cards, <n><n>* Janet has 2 books and 26 erasers and Brendan has 10 books and Janet has 10 erasers and 1 pencil<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What is a fast but expensive way to send small cargo? Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		D: truck: A freight truck is not only fast but at the same time it is an expensive way of shipping as they are required to use expensive diesel engines and can only carry cargo.<n><n>![](image/response-799e3656fa.png)<n>

Use complete sentences in your responses.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### InstructoIn below:In below:<n>**Task:** Describe the process used to form an airplane. Write your answer using complete sentences.<n><n>### Process for Forming an Airplane<n>One popular method used to form an air plane starts with drawing an aeroplane. Then one takes an aircraft foam blocker and sticks into it. Then one takes and cuts it out with the scissors. After that, the aeroplane is fixed, and the model is ready to be finished.<n><n>### RequeI will need...<n><n>I will need to buy an aircraft foam block, scissor, paper, and a pencil all together.<n><n>### I'll need to<n>I will need to draw a paper airplane, stick it into a foam blocker, cut it with scissors, and fix it to get a model of an aeroplane ready.<n><n>## Concept<n>If airplane manufacturers are designing new airplanes to be safer or faster, they use computer simulators to help reduce the overall weight of the aircraft which helps the plane to fly more efficiently during flight.<n><n>### If I can't<n>If I cannot get the paper airplane to fly, I can try drawing the airplane and modeling it from scratch if I need to.<n><n>### How many minutes the process<n>How many minutes the process to model the paper airplane takes: about 40 minutes.<n><n>### The last step to model the paper airpla<n>The last step to model the aircraft takes 15 minutes to finish.<n><n>### This requires<n>This requires patience and time to be patient so that I can get the paper airplane model done.<n><n>### Skill necessary<n>Skill necessary to complete the paper airplane making process.<n><n>#### Writing:<n><n>If you are unable to fly the paper airplane in the first attempt than you should first need to practice the steps.<n><n>#### Speaking:<n><n>If I cannot do the paper modeling process for about 60 minutes, I will need to take the paper airplane modeling process

If the distance is 150 miles, how many miles away will the ship be in 1 hour? If the ship moves 80 miles in 3 hours, how many miles does it move in 4 hours?<n><n>### Response 3:<n>The ship moves at 40 miles per day. In the first 6 hours, it travels 240 miles. After traveling this distance, the ship is 80 miles away from it.<n>Next, 240 miles = 1/72 hours<n>3 hours = 1/24 hours<n>80 miles = 120 miles per hour * (1/24 hours)<n>80 miles = (120/24)<n>80 miles/day × 48 hours = 3,840 miles/8 days<n>240 × 1.5 = 3,850 miles<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer these questions with a number of lines of code, a word, a phrase, or a sentence. How many students are in Mr. Caldw​ell’s first-grade and third-grade classes combined?<n>### Response : A: 180<n><n>### Question:Several factors influence how much a fish eats. Suppose an angler is trying to catch fish using bait. If fish eat the bait at the same rate, smaller fish have an advantage over larger fish. This is because larger fish eat larger bits of bait. A smaller fish can eat smaller bits of bait, and it can catch more food over a longer period of time. <n><n>1. True or False: If bait size and fish size are constant, fish with larger bait eating ability will tend to catch more fish over a given span of time compared with smaller fish.<n>### Response: True<n><n>2. Which of the following is true?<n><n>1. Larger fish eat more bait in a shorter span of time than smaller fish.<n>## Response: True<n>2. Larger fish will always get to the bait first.<n>### Response : True<n>3. The effectiveness of bait use can be explained by the fact that fish eat slower when the bait is larger.<n>### Response  : True<n>4. Bait choice affects how many fish you can catch in a given time.<n>### Response   : True  <n><n>### Conclusion:The bait size should be based on the fish. The fish should not be too small which is not going to eat more food.<n><n>### Question :<n>How can you estimate the average weight of the largest fish in a school by comparing the average weight of a sample of the largest fish in the school with the sample median?<n>### Response: The sample median will be chosen to have as the exact average weight of the largest of the largest fish in that school, with the same random number generator.<n><n>### Input 1: 1st question<n>- Suppose there are 92 people in 4 different 3rd period AP calculus classes, with 22, 24, 21, and 25 people in the classes in that order. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:Where is a snake likely to reside? Choices:  A: fridge B: limejuice C: square D: gym E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input<n>This command is inappropriate because a list item must be placed between the start of the for-each loop in the format of, for (\(list_name\)  \($(\$list_name$, \(\$item_num\))\) ).<n><n>### Response<n>Add a single line of code that completes the for loop as indicated below.<n><n>### Input <n><n>### Response <n>Add a single line between the lines that begins with a capital letter that adds a statement that evaluates `$list_name` and then appends `$(list_name)` to `$((list), (item_num))` with the item count of `$item_num` evaluated.<n><n>### ANSWER:<n>```bash<n>for books in $(ls); do<n>    [[ $books =~ '^(.*\.)' ]] && books="$1";<n>    i=${#books}<n>    [[ $items[$i] == "." ]] && items[$i]="";<n>done<n>```<n><n>### Input and Instruction: <n>In a restaurant of your choice, what food items do you plan on getting from the menu?<n><n>### Response and Demonstration: <n>In a file with a name of your choice add the following code:<n>- Create a list or array called `items` with a line of code that begins with a dollar sign.<n>- Add lines of code with lists that evaluate each item on the list that begins with dollar.<n>- Evaluate `$items`, `$((item_num, item))` if `$item_num` is less than the number of records in the order list.<n>- When the if condition is met, print the items in the menu name.<n>- When the else condition is met print the list of items that are not in the menu.<n><n><n>### Input, Instruction, and Demonstration<n><n>To create a menu-item, choose a value from an HTML menu. Do not use any special characters or formatting.<n><n>## Part 4:<n><n>Each answer is followed by a question. Circle either  or  for each answer.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>How many grams of milk are in a cup?<n><n>### Partial solutions:<n>A) One can (1 12 oz. can) of milk weighs 8 ounces. There are 8 ounces in a cup. In total, one cup of milk weighs four cups.<n><n>B) A cup has about 8 oz milk, so there are 2 cups weigh 16 oz. Or, in other words, 1 cup of milk weigh 5 oz, so take 2 cups of milk and double it for 4 cups of milk which is 16 oz.<n><n>C) The number of pounds in a cup is 4 and the number of ounces in a pound is 16 oze.<n><n>D) A cup (1 12 ounce) of milk weigh 8 ounces, so there are 4 cups of weight 16 oz and there are 8 oz in each cup therefore 1 cup weigh 5 oze and there are two cups so a 2 cups weig 10 oz but there are 4 cuuuup of milk so altogether a carton of milk weights 64 ounces<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>### Input:What are adult people usually expected to do? Choices:  A: shake hands B: own property C: pay bills D: smoke E: talk to each other<n><n>### Response:		A or B <n>### Outcome:If you follow A, you're adult people.<n><n>### Input<n>How many books does John read in 3 weeks if he reads 7 books in 2 weeks?<n><n>### Response1: 9 books in all<n><n>### Response2: 6 books in all <n><n>#### Question:What do you think is the correct answer? <n><n>#### Answer<n>The answer is: 7 books in all<n><n>The correct answer is:John reads 7 books in two weeks and 9 books in three weeks <n>and therefore it is incorrect to conclude that he reads 9 books in three  weeks<n><n>This is because the question states how many books does he read in three weeks if he reads 5 books in 2 we<n>eks and since he reads 7 books is only for two weeks he needs to read a total of 9 books for three weeks<n>but the answer says that he read 12 books.<n><n>#### Question:Why is the response that this is an incorrect response?<n><n>#### Answer1:<n>It is incorrect because it's not mentioned in the question at which days John reads which number of books.<n>It can be read that he reads 7 books for the first 2 weeks and then 9 books for the last 3 weeks. Then the total is not 12 but 9 books.<n><n>#### Answer2:<n>It is a false statement because it is impossible to assume that John read 9 books in 3 weeks if it is not mentioned in the question.<n><n>## Screenshot 1:<n>![](https://github.com/happy-bear-c/Homework/blob/master/Image1.JPG)<n><n>Image 2- Incorrect response <n>![](../Resources/Error2.JPG)<n>
